div.p: THE WIVES EXCUSE: OR, Cuckolds make Themselves. A COMEDY. As it is ACTED at the Theatre-Royal, BY Their MAJESTIES Servants.
div.q: Nihil est his, qui placere volunt, tam adversarium, quam expectatio. Cicero.
div.p: LONDON, Printed for W. Freeman, at the Bible in Fleet-street, near Temple-Barr, 1692.

div.head: TO Mr. Southern; ON HIS COMEDY, Called the WIVES EXCUSE.

lg.l: SUre there's a Fate in Plays; and 'tis in vain
To write, while these malignant Planets Reign:
Some very foolish Influence rules the Pit,
Not always kind to Sence, or just to Wit.
And whilst it lasts, let Buffoonry succeed,
To make us laugh; for never was more need.
Farce, in it self, is of a nasty scent;
But the gain smells not of the Excrement.
The Spanish Nymph, a Wit and Beauty too,
With all her Charms bore but a single show:
But, let a Monster Muscovite appear,
He draws a crowded Audience round the Year.
May be thou hast not pleas'd the Box and Pit,
Yet those who blame thy Tale, commend thy Wit;
So Terence Plotted; but so Terence Writ.
Like his thy Thoughts are true, thy Language clean,
Ev'n Lewdness is made Moral, in thy Scene.
The Hearers may for want of Nokes repine,
But rest secure, the Readers will be thine.
Nor was thy Labour'd Drama, damn'd or hiss'd,
But with a kind Civility, dismiss'd:
With such good manners as the The Wife in the Play, Mrs. Friendall. Wife did use,
Who, not accepting, did but just refuse.
There was a glance at parting; such a look
As bids thee not give o're, for one rebuke.
But if thou wou'dst be seen, as well as read;
Copy one living Author, and one dead;
The Standard of thy Style, let Etherege be:
For Wit, th' Immortal Spring of Wycherly.
Learn after both, to draw some just Design,
And the next Age will learn to Copy thine.
GAllants, you're welcome to our homely cheer:
If you have brought your English Stomachs here;
We'll treat you, as the French say, Cherentine.
And what we want of Humour, or of Wit,
Make up with your She-Neighbours in the Pit;
For on the Stage whate're we do, or say,
The Vizard Masks can find you better play:
With all our pains, we can but bring 'em in;
'Tis you must take the Damsels out agen:
And when we've brought you kindly thus together,
'Tis your fault if you're parted by foul weather.
We hope these natural Reasons may produce,
In every Whoremaster, a kind excuse
For all our Faults, the Poet's, and the Players,
You'l pardon us, if you can find out theirs. [To the Maskers.
But to the gentler Men, who love at sight,
And never care to come to closer fight,
We have provided work for them to night.
With safety they may draw their Cannon down,
And into a Surrender bomb the Town.
From both side-boxes play their Batteries;
And not a Bullet shot, but burning Eyes:
Those they discharge with such successful Arts,
They fire, three deep, into the Ladies hearts.
Since each Man here finds his Diversion,
Let not the damning of our Play be one.
But to the Ladies, who must sit it out,
To hear us prate, and see the Oglers shoot,
Begging their favour, we have this to say,
In hopes of their Protection for the Play,
Here is a Musick meeting every day.
MY Character, not being much in Vogue,
Has drawn me in to speak the Epilogue:
But, pray conceive me right, not to disparage
That ancient, English Perquisite of Marriage;
Which, when the Priests first made all Pleasure Sin,
Faster than they could cheat us, drew us in
With Rites and Liberties of Cuckolding.
That us'd to be the Custom, and so common,
No Girl but wish'd her self a Married Woman.
Whether I've done my Husband right, or no;
Most Women may be in the right, that do:
Our Author does not set up for reforming,
Or giving hints to Fools who won't take warning:
He's pleas'd, that other People are pleas'd too,
To help to reap that Harvest which they sow:
For among all the Cuckolds of this Town,
Who show themselves, and are as daily shown,
Our Poets may make some of 'em their own.
You find in me what may excuse a Wife:
Compare at home the Picture with the Life,
And most of you may find a Friendal there;
And most of you more justly us'd than here:
Our Author has his ends, if he can show,
The Women ne'er want cause for what they do:
For, Ladies, all his aim is pleasing you.
Some metled Sparks, whom nothing can withstand,
Your Velvet-Fortune-Hunters, may demand,
Why, when the means were in the Lady's hand,
The Husband civil, and the Lover near,
No more was made of the Wife's Charecter?
Damn me, cries one, had I been Betterton,
And struts, and cocks, I know what I had done;
She should not ha' got clear of me so soon.
You only fear such Plays may spoil your Game:
But Flesh and Frailty always are the same:
And we shall still proceed in our old way,
For all that you can do, or Poets say.

div.head: THE Wives EXCUSE, OR, Cuckolds Make themselves.
ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: The outward Room to the Musick-Meeting.
Several Footmen at Hazard, Some rising from Play.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: APox on these Musick Meetings; there's no Fifth Act
Here, a free cost, as we have at the Play-Houses,
To make Gentlemen of us, and keep us out of
Harms way: Nothing but Lice, and Link-Boys,
In this Anti-Chamber; or a merry Main to divert us;
And that merry Main, as you call it, makes most of us
Sad all the Week after.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Why, what hast thou done, Gill?

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: Undone my self, and a very good Friend of mine, my Belly,
For a Week forward: I am hungry already in the apprehension
Of wanting a Supper; for my Board-Wages
Is gone to the Devil with his Bones.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Six is the Main, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: That was my last Tester.

sp.speaker: 5 Foot.
sp.l: I'll play no more—

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Set out my hand, don't leave me so, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 6 Foot.
sp.l: Come, Sir, Seven to Six, I set you—

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Briskly my Boy.

sp.speaker: 6 Foot.
sp.l: I Set you this.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: How much?

sp.speaker: 6 Foot.
sp.l: Three halfperth of Farthings.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Three halfperth of Farthings?
sp.p: I see thou retain'st the Spirit of thy Ancestors, and as thou wert born, and bred, w●lt live rnd dye a Footman.
Three halfpenny worth of Farthings!

sp.l: He ●●●s like a Small beer Butler, in a Widdow-Lady's Family.
May'st thou starve under the tyranny of a House-keeper,
And never know the comfort of Board-wages again.
Well, well, I have my Money for all that.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: Why, what a Pretty Fellow have we here debauch'd from us,
And our Society, by living in a Civil Family! But this comes
Of keeping good hours, and living orderly: Idleness
After Supper, in your private houses, is the Mother
Of many mischiefs among the Maids.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Ay, ay, want of Employment has thrown him upon some
Gentle Chamber-maid, and now he sets up for good husbandry,
To Father her Failings, and get a Wet-Nurse for his Lady.

sp.speaker: 6 Foot.
sp.l: Better so, than to Father your Master's Bastards, as you do
Sometimes; or now and then cheat him of his Wench,
In the Convey, and steal his Clap from him.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: Gad I mercy i'faith, Lad.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: That indeed is a Sin I often commit, and sometimes repent of:
But, the good with the bad, I have no reason
To complain of my Service.

sp.speaker: 6. Foot.
sp.l: Pray don't trouble your head about mine then.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Come, come, we have all good Places if we can keep 'em:
And for my part, I am too deep in my Master's affairs, to fear
The losing of mine: What think you of the Family of the Friendals,
My Lads? a publick private Family, newly set up,
And of very fair Reception.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Ay, Dick. Thou hast the time on't indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.p: The Master of it frank and free, to make an Invitation to the whole Town; and the Mistress hospitable, and handsome,
sp.l: To give 'em wellcome, and content: For my Master knows
Every body, and contrives that every body shall know her.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Ay, marry Sir, there's a Family to breed up a Pimp in!
You may make a Fortune out of such a Mistress,
Before your Master can get her with Child.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: My Master has been married not a quarter of a year,
And half the young men in Town, know his Wife already;
Nay, know that he has known enough of her,
Not to care for her already.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: And that may be a very good argument for some of 'em,
To perswade her to know a little of some body else,
And care as little for him.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: A very good argument, if she takes it by the right handle

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Some of your Masters, I warrant you
Will put it into her hand.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: I know my Master has a design upon her.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: And upon all the Women in Town.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: Mine is in love with her.

sp.speaker: 5 Foot.
sp.l: And mine has hopes of her.

sp.speaker: 3. Foot.
sp.l: Every man has hopes of a new marry'd Woman
For she marries to like her Man; and if upon Tryal
She finds she can't like her Husband; she'll find some body else
That she can like, in a very little time, I warrant her,
Or change her Men 'till she does.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Let her like as many as she pleases, and wellcome:
As they thrive with her, I shall thrive by them:
I grind by her Mill, and some of 'em I hope will set it a going.
Besides, she has discover'd some of my Master's Intrigues of late.
That may help to fill the Sails; but I say nothing,
I will take Fees a both sides, and betray neither.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: If your Lady loves play, as they say she does, she will be
So far in your interest, that he that makes his Court to her,
Must have money to recommend him—

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: To me he must indeed, if he expects my assistance

sp.speaker: 5 Foot.
sp.l: Come, come, what do you think of my Master,
Mr. Lovemore, for the Lady?

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: I don't think of him.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Not so much as she does, I believe you; he's a generous Gentleman,
And deserves very well of her, and me.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: My Master, Mr. Wellvile is often at your House.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: He follows Mrs. Sightly, I can tell you.
But if your Lady, Mrs. Friendall, has a mind to be very well us'd;
Not to settle to't; but only by the way of a fashionable revenge,
Or so, to do her self justice upon her Husband; I look upon Mr. Wilding,
My Master, one or other, to be the cleverest Cuckold-Maker
In Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Not to settle to't indeed, for your Master is not over constant.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: He does not stay in a Family, to be challeng'd into Westminster Hall,
By the Husband's Action of battery, for an assault upon his Wife;
He is not so constant.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: Or if your Lady be dispos'd to the more refin'd part of an Amour,
Without the brutality, or design of enjoyment,
Only for the pleasure of being talkt of, or so forth—

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: Your Master Courtall will fit her to a hair:
For he will be as fond of the appearances of an Entrigue,
As she can be; to see him in the chase, you wou'd think
He had pleasure in the Sport; for he will be as sure
Always to follow her, as never to press her:
He will take as much pains, to put her undeservedly
Into a Lampoon, upon his account, as he would, to avoid
A handsome occasion, in private, to qualifie her for the scandal.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: In short, Mr. Courtall will do every thing,
But what he ought to do, with a Woman.

sp.speaker: 4 Foot.
sp.l: He has broke off with three Gentlewomen, upon my word,
Within these two Months, for coming on too fast upon that business.

sp.speaker: 2 Foot.
sp.l: Well, there are pretenders enow; so I have the profit,
Let my Lady take the pleasure of the choice:
I'm for the Fairest Bidder.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: What, Harry, hast thou nothing to say of thy Mistress, Mrs. Witwoud?

sp.speaker: 7 Foot.
sp.l: Nothing extraordinary, but that I ' mtir'd of her.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: She lives, as she us'd to do, least at home; has no Business
Of her own, but a great deal of other Peoples.
All the Men in Town follow her, but 'tis for other Women;
For she has frightned every one from a Design upon her:
Then she's a general Confidant; and sometimes reports
No more than she knows; but that's a favour indeed,
From a Wit, as they say she is.

sp.speaker: 7 Foot.
sp.l: If she be a Wit, I'll be sworn, she does not take me for one;
For she sends me very often upon very ridiculous Errands.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: I think you have a correspondent Porter, in every quarter
Of the Town, to disperce her scandalous Letters, which she is
Always bantering one Fool or other withall?

sp.speaker: 7 Foot.
sp.l: Four or Five always in pay with her.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: But when Horn-Fair comes, that's sure to be a Holy Day,
And every marry'd Man, that has a Wife handsomer than she is,
At her proper cost and charges, may expect a Fairing,
To put him in mind of his fortune.

sp.speaker: 7 Foot.
sp.l: I find you know her too well, to desire to live with her.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: I had rather be Master of the Ceremonies to a Visiting Lady,
To Squire about her how-d's-you, and Usher in the formal Salutations
Of all the Fops in Town, upon her day;
Nay, tho' she kept two days a week, than live in a Family with her.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: Will this damn'd Musick-Meeting never be done?
Wou'd the Cats-guts were in the Fidlers Bellies.

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.l: My Lady Smirkit's Page.

sp.speaker: 2 Page.
sp.l: Who's there? my Lady Woudmore!

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: At your dear Service, Madam.

sp.speaker: 2. Page.
sp.l: O Lord! Madam, I am surpriz'd to see your Ladyship here.—

sp.speaker: 2. Foot.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: 3. Foot.
sp.l: The Monkies Apeing their Ladies, let 'em go on.

sp.speaker: 2. Page.
sp.l: How can your Ladyship descend into these little Diversions
Of the Town, the Plays and the Musick-meetings?

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: Little Diversions indeed, Madam, to us, who have seen
So much better abroad, and still retain too much of the
Delicacy of the French, to be pleas'd with the Barbarous
Performances of these English.

sp.speaker: 3. Foot.
sp.l: That's a touch for some of 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: Yet there's no staying always at home, your Ladyship knows.—

sp.speaker: 2. Page.
sp.l: Nor being always seen in the Drawing-room, I vow, and swear:—

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: So that, Madam, we are almost under a necessity
Of appearing in these publick places.—

sp.speaker: 2. Page.
sp.l: An absolute necessity of shewing our selves sometimes.

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: Ay, but, Madam, then the men, they do so Ogle one.—

sp.speaker: 3. Foot.
sp.l: Ah! very well, Mr. Charles.

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: Into all the little Confusions,
That a Woman is liable to upon those occasions.

sp.speaker: 2. Page.
sp.l: I swear my Lord Simperwel has an irrisistible way with him.

sp.speaker: 1. Page.
sp.l: He ogl'd me all the Musick long, I believe every body
Took notice of it, so suriously, I could not bear it my self:
I vow and swear, he almost made me blush;
sp.p: And I wou'd rather do any thing to deserve blushing, in another place, than by a Country modesty betray such an unpardonable want of breeding, to the censure of so much good Company.

sp.speaker: 3 Foot.
sp.l: I dare swear for her Ladyship,
She had rather do it than blush for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.l: Why how now, Jack Sauce?
But did I blush, Madam?

sp.speaker: 2 Page.
sp.l: Only for your Friends, Madam, to see us so neglected.

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.l: Fye, fye, Madam, you made your Conquest too.
I minded no body but my Lord; and I vow and swear,
sp.p: I must own it, Madam, he ogles one more like a Man of Quality, than any body about Town, that I know of, and I think I am pretty well acquainted with all the soft looks in Town.

sp.speaker: 2 Page.
sp.l: One after another we have 'em all— but Jesu, Madam—

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.l: Ay, Madam.

sp.speaker: 2 Page.
sp.l: They say the French Fleet will be here next Summer,
With their Tourviles, and their things,
And, Jesu, Madam, Ravish us all.

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.l: O Lord, Madam, Ravishing us is nothing,
But our dear Religion, Madam, what will they do to that?

sp.speaker: 2 Page.
sp.l: Ay, what indeed, Madam?

sp.speaker: 1 Page.
sp.p: I wou'd not lose the gaping Galleries of our Churches, for the best Religion in Christendom.

sp.speaker: 3. Foot.
sp.l: You are pretious Pages indeed,
Betray your Ladies secrets, before you come in to 'em.
Make way for my Lord there, bear back Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Foot.
sp.l: So, so, 'tis done at last,
Let's get the Coaches to the door.

sp.stage: The Curtain drawn up, shews the Company at the Musick-Meeting; after an Italian Song, Lovemore, Wellvile, Wilding, Courtall, Springame, Friendall, Raffle, Mrs. Friendall, Sightly, Wittwoud, Fanny advance to the Front of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, how did you like the Musick?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: O very fine sure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: What say you to't, young Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: I have something to say to you, I like a great deal better,
Provided you won't laugh at me.
But the Musick's extreamly sine—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Especially the Vocal part.
For I did not understand a word on't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Nor I, faith, Wellvile, out the words were Italian.
They sung well, and that's enough for the pleasure of the Ear.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: By which I find your sense is sound.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: And sound sense is a very good thing, Courtall—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: That thou wot never be the better for.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Wilding, thou hast been so busie about that
Young Girl there, thou know'st nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: O, Sir, you're mistaken, I am a great Admirer—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Of every thing in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Of these Musical Entertainments; I am very Musical, and love any call, that brings the Women together.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Tho' it were a Cat-call.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Vocal, or Instrumental! which do you most approve of?
sp.p: If you are for the Instrumental, there were the Sonata's to night, and the Chacons, which you know—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The Sonata's and the Chacons which I know!
sp.p: Not I, Sir, I don't know 'em: they may be two Italian Fidlrs of your acquaintance, for any thing I know of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Fidlers! Masters, if you please, Wilding, Masters, excellent in their Art, and Famous for many admirable Compositions.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: So, he's fast in his own snare, with his Sonata's,
And Chacons: But how goes the World, Wilding?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The same Women every day, and in every publick appearance.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Here are some faces, I see, of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ay, Pox take 'em, I see 'em too often to forget 'em:
Wou'd their Owners thought as ill of 'em as I do,
sp.p: They would keep 'em at home: but they are for shewing their Show still, tho' no body cares for the sight.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis but good manners in Mr. Lovemore,
To be particular to your Sister, when her Husband
Is so Universal to the Company.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Prithee leave her to her Husband:
sp.p: She has satisfied her Relations enough in marrying this Coxcomb; now let her satisfie her self, if she pleases, with any body she likes better.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Fye, fye, there's no talking to you,
You carry my meaning further than I design'd.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Faith I took it up but where you left it,
Very near the matter.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: No, no, you grow scandalous; and I would not
Be thought to say a scandalous thing of a Friend.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Since my Brother in Law is to be a Cuckold,
As it must be mightily my Sister's fault, if he be not,
I think Lovemore as proper a Fellow to carry on
So charitable a work, as she cou'd ha' lit upon:
And if he has her consent to the business,
She has mine, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: A very reasonable Brother!

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Wou'd you would be as reasonable a Friend,
And allow me as many Liberties as I do her.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Why, so I will: she has the Men, and you shall have the Women,
The whole Sex to pick and chuse—

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: One Mistress out of—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: As many as you please, and as often as you have occasion.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Why, faith, that pleases me very well; you hit
My constitution, as if you were familiar with it,
Or had a mind to be so.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Not I indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: And I have, as you were saying—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: As I was saying!

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Very often an occasion for a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: You say so your self, I know nothing of your occasions.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Shall I bring you acquainted with some of 'em?
I have great variety, and have, every day, a new occasion
sp.p: For a new Mistress: If you have a mind to be satisfied in this point, let me go along with you—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Home with me?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Or home with me, will do my business as well.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But it won't do mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Then let it be home with you,
Tho' my Lodging is very convenient.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Why, this is suddain indeed, upon so small an acquaintance:
But 'tis something too soon for you,
And a little too late for me.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Not to repent, I hope, Madam? better late than never,
You know: Come, come, I have known
A worse offer better received.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: And this offer you will make to every Woman,
Till it be received, I dare answer for you.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: That's more than you can do for your self for refusing it.
sp.p: But the folly fall upon your own head: I have done my part, and 'tis your fault if you're idle—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: You have been entertain'd, Cozen—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: By a very pretty prating Fellow, Cozen;
sp.p: And I could be contented to let him show his parts this way, as often as he pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: What! like a man of Honour, he's for making good
What he says—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: And comes so quick upon that business, he won't afford
A Woman a reasonable liking-time, to make a decent
Excuse to her self, if she shou'd allowd 〈◊〉 a favour.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: The young Officer has heard enough of your Character,
I suppose, not to put it too much into your power
Of laughing at him.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I'm sorry fort: I would have a man know just enough
Of me, to make him a Lover; and then, in a little time,
I should know enough of him, to make him an Ass.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: This will come home to you one day.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: In any shape but a Husband, Cozen.
But methinks Lovemore, and Mrs. Friendall
Are very seriously engag'd—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I have had an Eye upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For such a trisle as Cuckolding a Husband is in this Town.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: The men will always design upon our Sex;
But I dare answer for her.—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And so will I. That if she should fall from the frailty of the Flesh, into that folly, she will appear no Monster,
sp.l: What ever her Husband may be.
What say you to a ramble after the Musick?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I say nothing to't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A Hackney jaunt, from one end of the Town to t'other?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: 'Tis too late.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I know two several Companies gone into the City,
One to Pontacks, and t'other to the Rummer, to Supper:
I want to disturb, strangely; what say you, Coz?
Let's put on our Masques, draw up the Glasses,
And send up for the Men, to make their Women uneasse:
There's one of 'em to be marry'd, it may do good upon her,
By shewing what she must trust to, if she will have a Husband.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: And can you be so mischievous?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Can you resist the Temptation?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I came with Mrs. Friendal, and must go home with her.
Look to your charge there.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I have an Eye that way.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: We shall see you to morrow, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: At your Toylet, Cousin; you are always
My first Visit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Is this your Friendship to Mr. Friendal?
I must not hear it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You see he gives you leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Therefore I can't take it; the Confidence is so generous,
That ev'n that wou'd secure me to him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: The Confidence is as generous on your side;
And do you think that will secure him to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I'll ask him, if you please.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You'll but disturb him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Mr. Friendal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Ha! what's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: There has happened her 〈◊〉 scurvy Dispute between me
And one of your Friends, Sir, as you think fit to call 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: A Dispute! about what, prithee? but before I hear
A word on't, Lovemore, thou art certainly in the wrong,
In holding an Argument with a Woman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I begin to think so too, Sir, for contending with a Lady,
That will be try'd by no body, but her Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: But what's the business?
Nothing extraordinary between you, I hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Believe me, Sir, I think it very extraordinary.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Very extraordinary indeed, Madam, to be so publickly
Expos'd for a private Opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: And you shall be the judge of the difference.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: No, no, no difference among Friends, it must not come to that,
I'le make up all differences between you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You may do much indeed to set all straight.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: And so I will, i'faith Lovemore, I'le reconcile all
I warrant you; but come, what is this mighty matter between you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I think it a mighty matter, Mr. Friendall, to be so far
Suspected in my Conduct, that any one, under the Title
Of your Friend, should dare, in your absense,
To be so very Familiar with me—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: How, Madam!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: All will out, I see.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: In my absence, so very familiar with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: As to censure these innocent Liberties that the Women
Allow themselves in the Company of their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: So, she has sav'd her Credit with me,
sp.stage: Mrs. Friendall joyns Mrs. Sightly, and Witwoud.
sp.l: And mine with her Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Why, Lovemore, thou art in the wrong of all this;
sp.p: I desir'd you to sport off a little Gallantry with my Wife, to Entertain and Divert her, from making her observations upon me, and thou dost nothing but play the Critick upon her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I find I was mistaken.
But how wou'd you have me behave my self?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Why, I wou'd have you very frequent in your Visits,
And very obliging to my Wife: Now and then, to carry on
Our other Pleasures the better: For an amusement, or so,
You may say a Civil thing to her, for every Woman, you know,
Loves to have a Civil thing said to her sometimes;
But then you must be very cautious in the expression;
If she shou'd in the least apprehend that you had a design
Upon her, 'twou'd raise the Devil in one part of the Family,
And lay him in another, perhaps, where I had a mind to employ him:
Therefore I wou'd have you keep in Favour with her—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'le do my best, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: She's inclining, you must know, to speak very well of you;
And that she does of very few of the Men, I assure you:
She approves of the intimacy and Friendship between us,
And of your coming to the House; and that may
Stand you instead with the Lady, you wot off—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I apprehend you— so begging the Ladies Pardon
With a design of doing something to deserve it.—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That will never fail with the Women, Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I will make an Interest with the Masters,
To give you a Song at parting.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: An English Song, good Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: O by all means, an English Song.

sp.speaker: Welvile.
sp.l: Any Song, which won't oblige a Man.
To tell you, he has seen an Opera at Venice to understand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Pray, let him sing the Ladies the Song I gave him.

sp.speaker: Musick-Master.
sp.l: Which Song, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: The last.

sp.speaker: Musick-Master.
sp.l: 'Tis not set, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Not set, Sir!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: That's a Fault he'll never forgive you.

sp.speaker: Musick-Master.
sp.l: Why, really, Sir, I would serve any Gentleman to my power;
But the Words are so abominably out of the way of Musick,
I don't know how to humour 'em: There's no setting 'em,
Or singing 'em, to please any body, but himself.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: O! but we lose by this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Hang e'm, idle Rascals; they care not what Entertainment
We lose, so they have but our Money.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Is it your own Song, Mr. Friendall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I must not rob your Ladyship of your Part in it.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: My Part in your Song, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: You were the Muse that inspir'd me;
I writ it upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Fye, fye; That Pride wou'd ruin me:
But I know you say so to every Woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I gad, she's i'th' right on't;
I have told a Dozen so already at the Musick-meeting,
And most of 'em believe me.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Does Mr. Friendall often write Songs, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: He does many things, he shou'd not do, Madam;
But I think he loves me, and that excuses him to me:
Tho', you may be sure, 'tis with the tenderest Concern for my own
Reputation, that I see my Husband daily trifle away his
So notoriously, in one Folly or other of the Town.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: For his own Reputation, it must be;
For the World will believe, she turns such a Husband
To the right Use, whatever she says to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Mr. Friendall, pray be satisfied with a good Estate;
And not imagine, because you have that, you have every thing else.
The business of writing Songs should be over with a married Man.
And since I can't be suspected to be the Phillis, or Cloris.
'Tis an Affront to me, to have any other Woman thought so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Indeed, Madam, so far you are right:
I never heard of any Man, that writ a Song upon his Wife.

lg.l: INgrateful Love! Thus every Hour,
To punish me by her Disdain!
You tyrannise to show your Power;
And She, to triumph in my Pain.
You, who can laugh at Humane Woes,
And Victims to her Pride decree,
On me, your yielding Slave, impose
Your Chains; but leave the Rebel free.
How fatal are your poyson'd Darts!
Her conqu'ring Eyes the Trophies boast,
Whilst you insnare poor wandring Hearts,
That in her Charms and Scorn are lost.
Impious, and Cruel: You deny
A Death, to ease me of my Care;
Which she delays, to make me try
The force of Beauty, and Despair.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Lovemore, We may thank you for this:
But when you keep your Promise to me, at Dinner, to Morrow,
And you, and you, and all of you, Gentlemen,
I'll do you Reason to the good Company.
Some of my Servants there.—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Madam, I am very luckily here to offer you my Service.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: No particular Woman must expect it from so general
A Follower of the Sex, as Mr. Courtall is.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: A general Follower of the Sex indeed, Madam,
In my Care of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Besides, 'tis dangerous to be seen with a Man of your Character;
For if you don't make it an Intrigue, the Town makes it for you:
And that does most of your Business as well.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: There's no knowing a Man by his Character in this Town;
The Partiality of Friends, and the Prejudice of Enemies, who divide it,
Always make him better or worse than he deserves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: If you have no regard to my Reputation, pray be tender of your own.
'Tis now-a-days as scandalous in a Man, who wou'd be thought to know
The Town (as I know you wou'd) to wait upon a bare Face to her Coach,
As it us'd to be to lead out a Vizard-Mask:
But the Pit has got the better of the Boxes,
With most of you, in that point of Civility;
And I don't doubt, but it turns to better Account.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Indeed, Sister, it does turn to better Account;
And therefore we must provide for our selves.—
sp.stage: Takes Courtall with him. To Mrs. Witwoud.
sp.l: Why, here's a Woman, Courtall—
If she had a Vizard-Mask to encourage me—
I cou'd go to the World's end with her:
But, as she is, bare-fac'd, and an honest Woman—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You'll do a foolish thing, for once; see her to her Coach,
I dare say for you, to make her otherwise.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Why, if it must be so—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You own your Aunt is a-bed; and you see Mrs. Witwoud's
Too busie to mind your going away with me.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.l: I can't to night, but I'll call upon you to morrow morning,
As I go to Six a Clock Prayers.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I hope, Madam, I may without exception wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Welvile.
sp.l: And, Madam, I have the Title of an old Servant to your Ladyship,
To expect that favour from you—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Mr. Friendall, having a handsome Wife in the Company,
May be jealous; and you will pardon me,
If I am unwilling to give him a suspicion of a Man,
Whom I would have every body think as well of, as I do my self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Mr. Friendall gives you more opportunities than I can approve of,
And I cou'd wish you wou'd not take the advantage of 'em,
They'll turn to no account.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Come, Ladys, I am your Man I find—

sp.speaker: Ruffle.
sp.l: What think you of this occasion?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You can't have a better; follow him—
And be famous—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: What have you now in hand?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Why all my hopes of the Wife depending upon the
Senceless behaviour of the Husband:
I have contriv'd, by this Fellow, before her face too, to expose
Him, a way, that must ruine him with her for ever;
Let's follow, and expect the event—

sp.speaker: Link-boy.
sp.l: Have a light Gentlemen, have a light, Sir,

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Light your selves to the Devil.

sp.speaker: 2 Link B.
sp.l: Bless you Master, we can find the way in the dark.
Shall I light your Worship there?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Then call a Coach, and thy Wit shall be thy reward.

sp.speaker: 5 Foot.
sp.l: Mr. Friendall's Coach there—
sp.stage: Mr. Friend. enters, leading Mrs. Sightly with his Wife, Ruffle enters after 'em. Lovemore and Wellvile in the rear.
sp.l: 'Tis at the door, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I must improve ' every opportunity
With your Ladyship, to convince you of the truths
I have been telling you to night, and in this
Billet, I give it under my Hand how very much
I am your Servant—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Fye, fye, before your Wife—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Sir, that Paper don't belong to you.
sp.stage: Friendall leads Mrs. Sightly off, and returns for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Ruffle.
sp.l: Don't be jealous, Lady, I know no design
The Gentlewoman has as yet upon my Person
And I'll belong to you, if this Gentleman pleases.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: You're pleas'd to be merry, Sir, but no touching her, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: What wou'd the Fellow have?

sp.speaker: Ruffl.
sp.l: Why, I wou'd have this Fellow gone about his business.

sp.speaker: Mr. Friend.
sp.l: My Business lies here at present, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raffle.
sp.l: You lye there, Sir.
sp.stage: Hits Mr. Friendall a box on the ear, and draws, the Women shriek, Mrs. Friendall pretends to hold her Husband, the Company come about 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Good Mr. Friendall, another time,
Consider where you are.
You are more a Man of honour, I know, than to draw your Sword
Among the Women; I am sorry this has hapned in a place
Where you can't right your self, without wronging the Company.
But you'll find a time to do a justice to your self, and the Ladies,
Who have suffer'd in the apprehension of such a brutality.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: I'll go along with you—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Wou'd the Devil had 'em, for drawing their Swords here;
I have lost my little Captain in the fray:
My Charge is departed too, and for this night I suppose has left me
To make an excuse to the Family, for her lying abroad
With a Country Cozen, or so; that Rogue Wilding has carry'd
Her home with him, and 'tis as well now, as a week hence,
For when these young Wenches once set their hearts upon't,
Every thing gives them an opportunity to ruine themselves:
Her Aunt Teazall has made her rise to Six a Clock Prayers, to sine
Purpose, if this be the fruits of her Devotion: but since she must
Fall to some body, I'm glad Wilding has her, for he'll use her ill enough
In a little time, to make her wiser for the future,
By the dear experience, and vexation of this Intrigue,
(Being disappointed of many things she expects)
She may make a virtue of necessity, repent because she can't keep him to her self,
And make an honest man a very good Wife yet.

sp.speaker: Ruffle.
sp.l: I have done my part, and am satisfied
With the honour of the Atchievement.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: 'Tis a reputation clear-gain'd.
Since there's no danger of accounting for't.

sp.speaker: Ruffle.
sp.l: So thanking you, for this occasion of shewing my self,
I am your humble Servant—

sp.speaker: Wellvile.
sp.l: Who is this Hero, pray?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why this is a Spark, that has had the misfortune of being kick'd very lately, and I have helpt him to this occasion of repairing his honour, upon our very good friend, a greater Coward than himself:
sp.l: He has serv'd my ends, now let him serve the Towns.

sp.speaker: Wellv.
sp.l: But did you observe how the Lady behaved her self
In the Quarrel, to conceal her Husband's Cowardise?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: What a handsome excuse she made in his favour, to the Company?
When she can never make any for him to her self.

sp.speaker: Wellvile.
sp.p: This matter well manag'd, may turn to account; tho' you must not be seen to expose him, you may take the advantage of his exposing himself.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And let her say what she can, upon this subject, I believe no Woman can be contented to have her Honour, much longer than her Fortune in the possession of a Man, who has no fund of his own, to answer in security for either.
sp.l: Thus, who a Married Woman's Love wou'd win,
Shou'd with the Husband's failings first begin;
Make him but in the fault, and you shall find
A Good Excuse will make most Women kind.

div.head: ACT the Second, SCENE I.
div.stage: Witwou'd at a Table, with Betty, and a Footman waiting.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: NO News of my Cozen Fanny this morning?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: For God's sake, Madam, not a word of her lying out
To night, we shall have the Devil to do
With the Old Gentlewoman, if she knows it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's a secret I can keep from her, for my own sake, Betty:
But how comes this about? I'm quite out of Gilt Paper;
Harry, you fetch me two or three Quire from Mr. Bentleys,
And call at Mrs. Da Robe's, my Mantoa-Womans,
As you come back, for Letters— and d'you hear?
Give this Note to Joe the Porter, he needs no instructions;
Let him leave it for Mr. Wilding—
I find I must meddle in this business;
For her Visits at this rate, will not only be troublesome
To him (as I would have 'em) but in a little time,
Be publick to the whole Town:
Now, tho' I am very well pleased with any matter
Of Scandal; I am so nearly related to the interest
Of this Girl, I wou'd not have her the occasion of it.
They say the Understanding ought to be suited
To the Condition, to make any one happy:
Wou'd she were in a Condition suitable
To her Understanding; she has wit enough
For a Wife, and nothing else that I know of.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: O, Madam! you're wellcome home.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Rather good morrow, Cozen.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Rather good morrow indeed,
That's the properer Salutation:
For you're never to be seen in your Lodging
At any other time of the day; and then too,
As soon as you're out a Bed in a morning,
You Summon a Congregation of your Fellows
Together, to hear you prate by the hour,
Flatter every body in the Company,
Speak ill of every one that's absent,
And scatter about the scandal of that day.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why, Madam, you won't quarrel at that, I hope,
'Tis one of the most fashionable, innocent
Diversions of the Town,
It makes a great deal of mirth, speaking ill of People,
And never does any body any harm.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Not with any that know you, I believe.
How came you home last night?
The night before, you arriv'd like a Carted Bawd,
Justly punished for the Sins of the People.
You confess'd you were forc'd to bilk your Coach,
To get rid of the Coxcombs, that dog'd you
From the Play-House, and being pursu'd
By the Coachman, and Footmen (for I don't doubt
But you gave the Gentlemen encouragement enough,
To come home with you) you lookt as if
You belong'd to a Cellar, in some of the Allies
You were hunted through, and had been
Caterwawling in all the kennels in Town.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That was an unfortunate night indeed.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Well, deliver every good womans Child, I say,
From such daggle-tail'd Courses as these are;
What will be the end of 'em, I beseech you?
You will make your self as odious in a little time,
As you endeavour to make every body else:
This is not the way to get a Husband;
The Men know too much of you already,
To desire any more of you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I don't set up for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Marry come up here! You may have
An occasion for an Husband, when you can't get one,
Husbands are not always to be had at a months
Warn'ng, to finish anothers work:
What, 'tis beneath the Character of a she Wit,
● suppose, to be constant: or is a Husband
Out of fashion of you forsooth?
Another Woman's husband can go down with you,
To my knowledge, and as ugly a Rogue too,
With as hanging a Countenance, as I cou'd wish
Any Villain I had a mind
To be rid of— your diversion, as you call him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O spare my shame, I own he is my curse,
Doom'd for my plague, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Spare your shame! I'll say that for you,
You have not been sparing of any endeavour,
That cou'd bring a shame any way into the Family
Wherever you lived yet; if there was ever a Fool
Soft enough to throw it upon.
All your Relations know you, and are afraid
To have you in a House with 'em:
And I suppose you are very well pleas'd to be
From under their roof; to have your Fellows come
After you, to my House, as they do;
And as I am Fool enough to allow of.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For no harm, Cousin, I hope.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Perhaps you think it no harm;
And, indeed, it can't easily do you any harm:
But, I'm sure, I have one of my Nieces
Already undone, by your bringing her
Acquainted with some of 'em.
I was forc'd to marry her, you know,
Below her Rank (for the usual Reason
Of this End of the Town) into the City,
Where 'twas less scandalous, the Wives there
Having a Charter for what they do.
And now Fanny, a very Girl, when I have provided
A Husband, and all, for her, (for she must have a Husband,)
She takes after her Sister; (as a little thing
Will make a President for what we are
Inclined to;) she takes after her Sister, I say,
And is unfortunately engaged in a Passion
For Mr. Wilding: And how to prevent it—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Indeed, I must acknowledge I was, in a great
Measure, the unfortunate Cause of my Cousin
Biddy's Miscarriage; but for my Cousin Fanny,
Rely upon me; nothing shall come on't:
I am now going to Mr. Wilding
On that Account; and have sent a Note
To secure him at his Lodgings till I come.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Well, Where's this Girl?
Why does not she come, when I send for her?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Madam, she went to Six-a-Clock Prayers,
And is not come back yet.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: God's Bodykins! Has she got the trick on't?
Of abusing the Church into the place
Of Assignation already?
Wilding has carry'd her home with him.
That's certain: Get you gone after her;
May be you may prevent his wicked
Design on her. Go, go, and redeem her,
Tho' you leave your self in her room.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I'm oblig'd to you, truly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: I dare venture you,
You'll not be in Love with him;
You'll give him as good as he brings;
And, let the worst come to the worst,
You have lived too long in the Town,
To be uneasie for any Man;
Or be concern'd beyond the Pleasure
And Convenience of the Intrigue.
Therefore I may venture you, a little time
Goes a great way in this business; deliver her,
And I won't find fault with you, these three days
You shall do what you please—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Nay, Mr. Friendall, I know what you will object to me;
But you must hear me out.
The concern, and care of your reputation,
Is as dear to me, as it can be tender to you;
Since I must appear to the world, only in that rank of honour,
Which you are pleas'd to maintain.

sp.speaker: Mr Fr.
sp.l: Why, Madam, you have as handsome an Equipage
As any Man's Wife in Town, that has a Father alive.

sp.speaker: Mrs Fr.
sp.l: This must not put me off,
I see you make little of the matter, to hide it from my fears;
And there indeed you're kind: but 'tis in vain
To think of concealing from me, what you intend,
From what you ought to do, I know what you will do,
After so base a wrong.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: A Drunken extravagance, the Fellow
Will be sorry for't, when he's sober—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: If you wou'd stay till then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: And beg my pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs Fr.
sp.l: That he shall do, if that wou'd satisfie you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Satisfie me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: And let it satisfie you,
It ought to satisfie you from such a one.
For, I believe he wou'd not have quarrel'd any where else,
Nor there neither, but upon the prospect
Of being prevented, or parted, or secur'd over night,
In order to beg pardon in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Ay, Madam, but consider—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Pray consider me, Mr. Friendall;
I must suffer every way, if you Proceed to a revenge;
In your danger, which must be mine;
In my honour, which ought to be more yours;
Than to expose it upon every little occasion—
Come, come, in other things you have a good
Opinion of my conduct, pray let me govern here:
You may be assur'd, I'll do nothing to lessen you,
The satisfaction shall be as publick as the affront.
Leave it to me for once, I won not be deny'd—
He is not worth your danger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Well, you shall govern me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: What you are a marry'd man;
And have a good Estate settled upon you;
And shou'd not be accountable to every idle Rake-hell.
That has a mind to establish a Renown,
From being troublesome to publick places.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: What then wou'd you propose?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: A small request; not to stir abroad,
Nor be at home to any body, 'till you hear from me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I promise you I won't—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I dare take your word:
His lameness last Night,
And backwardness this Morning,
In resenting that blow, satisfie me
That he is not in a Fever for Fighting:
I don't know that he is a Coward;
But having these reasons to suspect him,
I thought this was my best way to hinder him
From discovering himself.
For if he had betray'd that baseness to me,
I shou'd despise him; and can I love the Man I most despise?
Brother, I sent for you—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: To make up this quarrel I know, and I come to lend
A helping hand to the work,
I design to be a Second in the business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: You must be my Second then,
For I have taken the Quarrel upon me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: With all my heart, I gad;
We, who live all the Summer for the Publick,
Shou'd live in the Winter for our selves—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: And the Women, good Captain—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: That's living for our selves,
For 'tis not living without 'em:
And a Duel now might but interrupt a Month
Of other Business perhaps, that would be more agreeable
To my constitution, I assure you:
Then we are to have no fighting it seems?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: For Reasons I'll tell you hereafter.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Nay there was no great danger of it;
I have found out the Gentleman's Lodgings, and Character.
We shall strike up a Peace before a Bottle's to an end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: This Challenge must be deliver'd as from him;
I trust the management to you:
Only take this in advice, that Mr. Friendal
Wants your assistance within; you must stand by him,
And oblige the Gentleman to make him satisfaction,
Without bringing his Person in danger.
And he shall satisfie him, or me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I understand you, and he shall satisfie him, or me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: See him satisfied, and I'll satisfie you, with something
Shall be better to a younger Brother,
Than the false Musters of a Winters quarter.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Whatever I think of him, I must not let him fall
Into the Contempt of the Town: Every little Fellow,
I know, will be censoriously inquisitive,
And maliciously witty, upon another Man's Cowardise,
Out of the pleasure of finding as great a Rascal as himself.
How despicable a Condition must that Matrimony be,
When the Husband (whom we look upon as a Sanctuary for a
Woman's Honour) must be obliged to the Discretion
And Management of a Wife,
For the Security of his own!
Have a care of thinking that way;
For in a marry'd State, as in the publick,
We tye our selves up, indeed; but to be protected
In our Persons, Fortunes and Honours,
By those very Laces, that restrain us in other things;
For few will obey, but for the Benefit
They receive from the Government—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Madam, Mr. Lovemore—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Lovemore here!
I know he comes to tempt me to rebel;
But I'm prepar'd for him.—
Good Morrow Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I cou'd not expect to see your Ladyship so early:
I come to Mr. Friendall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: May I thank you for the Visit?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I came as a Friend, you may be sure, Madam:
Where your Honour's concern'd, I can't be an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Not reasonably, indeed, to any Man that wou'd injure it,
Since you are a profess'd Enemy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: An Enemy!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Unless you will allow no body to ruin it,
But your self.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Indeed, I wou'd allow no body to defend it, but my self,
If I had the keeping of it: But a happier Man
Has that Title, and I can only hope
To be a Second in your Service.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I thank you for the Service you design me;
But that happier Man, as you call him,
Who has the Title, will maintain it, it seems;
For he, and my Brother Springam, I'm afraid,
Are gone about it already.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Gone, Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: An Hour ago, before I had notice to prevent 'em:
For Mr. Friendall, you may be sure,
Was impatient for an Occasion of righting himself.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I might have thought so, indeed, Madam:
Wou'd I had come sooner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: You may yet be serviceable to me, Sir, tho' you are too late for Mr. Fr.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: How, Madam, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: By endeavouring to prevent 'em: You are acquainted.
With the Ways of reconciling Matters of this
Honourable Nature. I am going to make an Interest with a Kinsman,
A Collonel of the Guards, my self, to secure 'em.
Let your good Nature in this, be a Proof of your Friendship;
And command me to my Power.—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Prevent 'em! Yes, yes: That I must do for my own sake:
For if he shou'd behave himself better than I imagin'd he wou'd,
It may secure him in his Wife's Esteem, and only
Ruin me with her, who laid the Design.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Have you dispos'd of her?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Safe into a Chair, Sir; she's jogging homeward,
Lighter by a Maiden-head, I presume, than she came, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The Loss is not so light, but she may feel it.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Heavy enough, perhaps, nine Months hence, Sir.
But have you sent ever a Lye along with her?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: pardon me, Sir: Not that I believe your Honour
Was sparing of your Conscience, in saying any thing,
And swearing to't, that she had a mind to believe.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That you may swear, indeed.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: But she's gone away so very well satisfy'd
With what you have said and done to her,
She's above inventing a Lye for her self:
The first angry Word they give her at home,
I suppose, you may hear of her; a Hackney-Coach
Removes her, and her Commodes, upon very little warning;
And I expect when she will send in half a dozen
Band-boxes, to take possession of your Lodgings.
But, pray Sir, if I may be so bold—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Yes, yes; at this time you may be so bold:
The Service of your Wit secures you the Privilege of your Jest.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Then, pray Sir, why did you take so much pains
To persuade this young Creature to come away
From her Aunt, when I know you never design
To take care of her your self?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why, 'Faith, I can't make you a very good Answer:
But the best Reason I know of, is,
(Besides the Reputation of undoing her)
It looks kind, at the time, to talk of providing
For the Woman that does one the favour.
'Twas a very plausible Argument, to cozen her into a Consent;
Level to my Design of Lying with her,
And carry'd to the very Mark of Love.
Indeed, it costs nothing to promise,

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: When nothing can oblige you to pay:
And if she depends upon it, at her peril;
'Tis she will be disappointed, not you;
Tho' Ten to One, poor little Rogue, from the Fondness
Of her own Inclinations, she guesses at yours:
And fancies, from the Courtesie she has done you,
You will be so civil a Gentleman, to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not unlikely: There's none of these young Girls,
(Let a Man's Character be never so loose among 'em,)
But, from one Vanity, or other, will be encouraged to design and venture upon him: And tho' Fifty
Of their Acquaintance have fall'n in the Experiment,
Each of them will still imagine, she has something,
Particular, in her Person, forsooth, to reclaim,
And engage him to her self. So most of 'em
Miscarry, upon the Project of getting Husbands,

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Gad forgive me for Swearing; but, as I hope to be sav'd,
And that's a bold Word for a Foot-man 〈◊〉 beg your Pardon;
There's a Lady below, in a Vizard, to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Get you gone, you Rascal; beg her Pardon, and Leave
To wait upon her: She wou'd have been admitted, in less time,
To a Privy Counsellors leave, though he had laid aside
The Business of the Nation, to manage hers.
This must be the Letter-Lady:
She comes a little unseasonable, if she knew all:
If she has Experience enough to allow for some Natural
Miscarriages, which may happen in the beginning
Of an Amour, I may pacifie her that way:
'Tis but swearing heartily, damming the Modesty
Of my Constitution, laying its Faults upon an Over-respect
To her, and promising better things for the future:
That us'd to be a current Excuse; but 'tis the Women's Fault,
If it pass too often upon 'em.—
If she prove an old Acquaintance, the Coldness of the
Entertainment will secure me from the Persecution of her Visits
Hereafter: But if it be a Face I never saw,
I may use her well enough yet, to encourage her
To another Appointment. So every way does my Business,
Whatever becomes of the Ladies.—
O, Madam, I beg your Pardon.—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: No Excuses, good Sir; Men of Employment are above
Good Breeding; and I see you have a great deal upon your hands,

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am a Man of Business, indeed, Madam;
And, as you were pleas'd to signifie in your Letter,
My Practice lies among the Women:
What can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Can't you tell what, Sir? You are not the Man I took you for:
But you are like our Fortune-tellers,
Who come into our Secrets, more by our own Folly,
In betraying our selves, than by any Skill
Or Knowledge of their own.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Indeed I shou'd ha' proceeded, as most of those Fellows do,
Set out impudently at first, taken several things
For granted (as that you were no Maid, and so forth)
Ventur'd briskly at every thing, and something
Might have hapned to please you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Did the Lady, just gone away from you, find it so?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: She had what she came for: You wou'd take it ill,
To lose your labour your self, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: She ventur'd at every thing, as briskly
As you cou'd, I suppose, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: 'Tis a towardly Girl indeed, and comes on sinely;
I have no reason to complain of losing my labour
Upon her: She's ready for running away
From her Relations already.
Are not you a little that way inclin'd? Come, come,
If you have any troubles upon your 〈◊〉, Child—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You can remove 'em into the Flesh, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: If you have ever a Husband, that lies heavy
Upon your Conscience, I have a Cordial
Will drive the Distemper from your heart.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why that's kind indeed, to make some room for the Lover:
But that is not my Distemper: I cou'd resolve it my self,
If I had a Husband, whether I wou'd make him a Cuckold, or no:
But I lie under a Difficulty of disposing of a Maiden head,

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: There I must resolve you, that case I often handle.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But hear if, I beseech you, before you decide it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That wou'd do well in Westminster-hall, I grant you,
But in Proceedings of this nature, we are always
On the Plaintiffs side: Let the sober Party say what they can
To the reason of the thing.
You are certainly in the right, in pleasing your self.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Twill come to that, I believe: For you must know, Sir,
That being under the Discretion, and Tyranny of an old Aunt—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You will naturally run away from her.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And being considerable enough, to be followed for my Fortune—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You will certainly be betray'd, and Sold by her—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: To some Booby of her own Breed, who paying too dear
For the Purchase, will undo himself, to undo me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come, come, you are now under my Care,
'Tis my Fault, if you miscarry—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And mine too if I do.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Let me be your Trustee—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Indeed the Woman shou'd cheat the Man, as much as she can,
Before Marriage, because, after it,
He has a Title of cheating her, as long as he lives.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: If you can't make over your Money,
Make over your—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Common conveyances both in our Sex, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: A Maiden-head's a Jewel of no value in Marriage—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Tis never set down indeed,
In the particular of a Womans Estate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And therefore least mist by a Husband,
Of any thing she brings along with her.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If indeed, by the articles of Marriage, a Man should convenant
For a Maiden-head, the Woman,
In a legal honesty, ought to satisfie the Bargain,
But the Men never mention that,
For fear of inflaming the Joynture.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And the Women never put 'em upon't,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Out of a Conscience in their dealings to be sure, for fear
They shou'd not always be able to be as good as their words.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I see, Madam, we differ only in our Sexes;
And now, if you please, we will begin
A right understanding between them two.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'll shew you how: have a care what you do, Madam,
'Tis a very difficult matter, let me tell you,
To refuse a man handsomly,
Look you, Madam, I would have you make a decent resistance,
A little of it enhaunces the favour,
And keeps up the value of your Person,
But too much on't is an undervaluing of mine.
Nay, nay, when it once comes to fighting,
You often ruine what you wou'd raise.
Strugling too long, is as much to your disadvantage,
As not strugling at all; and you know 'tis the same thing
To a Woman, a Mans being indifferent,
As his being incapable to oblige her—
Come, come, enough of this—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So I say too, Sir, the jest will go no further, I see.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Mrs. Witwoud! I did not expect
sp.stage: [Unmasks, he declines into a respect to her.
sp.l: To see you here, indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I came upon business, Mr. Wilding, but the temptation
Of a Vizard Mask, and the pleasure of prating
Upon such an occasion, has carried me a little beyond it,

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am oblig'd to you, for a great deal of wit,
Whatever else you design me by this visit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Which now you hardly thank me for;
Since 'tis impossible for an old Acquaintance,
To answer your expectations of a new face.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: To shew how I value your visit, and the regard
I have for you, I will give some necessary Orders in the Family,
To prevent your being seen in my Lodgings,
And wait upon you agen.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: By this extraordinary care of my reputation,
I find he has no design upon it himself:
Not that I have any design upon Mr. Wilding;
But I am sorry to find, that every Man
Has not a design upon me; for since want is the rate of things,
I know no real value of Reputation,
But in regard of Common Women, who have none;
No extraordinary worth of a Maiden-head.
But as 'tis a temptation to the Man to take it away;
And the best commendation of Virtue is,
That every Man has a design to put it to the tryal.
It vexes me tho' to think he shou'd grow so tame,
Upon the sight of me; not that I believe,
I had any thing in my face, that alter'd him;
Something did, that's certain; by which I find
'Tis not enough for a Woman to be handsome,
There must be a probability of making that handsome Woman kind,
To make a Man in love with her,
For no Man is in love without some encouragement
To hope upon: Now from one of my Character,
Who have impertinently prated away so much of my time,
(In setting up for a Wit, to the ruine of other Peoples pleasure,
And loss of my own) what encouragement,
Or probability can there be, but that, as I have liv'd a fool,
I ought to dye repenting, unpity'd, and a Maid:
If I had dy'd a Maid, 'tis but what I deserv'd,
For laughing so many honest Gentlemen
Off their charitable design of making me otherwise.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Now, Madam, you command me.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It shall be to do your self a favour then, Mr. Wilding,
To rid you of an incumbrance, which lies as heavy
Upon your pleasures, as a Wife upon her Husband.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: O defend me from a Wife.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And from a silly Mistriss, Sir, the greater burthen of the two:
A Wife you may lay aside, but a foolish fond Mistriss,
Will hang about you, like your Conscience, to put you in mind
Of your Sins, before you are willing to repent of 'em:
You know whom I mean, Mr. Wilding, you may trust me
With the secret, because I know it already.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That's one very good Reason truly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: My Cozen Fanny indeed is very well in her person—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Very well to be lik'd I mean.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I mean so too, Madam:
Tho' I have known a Clap mistaken for a Maiden-head, before now.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But she's a Girl, and I can guess how very unfit
A Girl must be, to give you any desire beyond undoing her:
For I know your temper so well,
(Now you have satisfy'd the curiosity or vanity of your love)
You would not bear the punishment of her Company another day,
To have the pleasure of it another night,
Whatever you have said to perswade her to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Fy, Madam, think better of me.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Better, nor worse, than I do of all the young men in Town: For I believe you wou'd now resign her to any body else, with as much satisfaction, as you got her for your self: I know most of those matters end in the benefit of the Publick: and a little of your ill usage (which you will take care to supply her withall) may make her one of the common goods of the Town: But that's a ruine I wou'd prevent if I cou'd: Therefore, to save you the labour of getting rid of her (for that's the only design you have now upon her, I'm sure) I came to spare your good Nature the trouble, by making you a very fair Offer.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Let's see how reasonable you can be, in another body's Bargain.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Very reasonable you shall find me, if you will but give over your farther attempts upon her, (which now you may easily be persuaded to I suppose) and contribute, by your assistance, to my design of marrying her: I will engage my self and interest (which you know is very considerable in my own Sex) to serve you in any other Woman of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith, Madam, you bid like a Chapman

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Any Woman, of any Family or Condition, the best Friend I have I'll befriend you in, and thank you into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Stay, Let me consider, Which—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: But take this advice along with you; Raise the Scene of your affairs above the conquest of a Girl. Some of you Sparks think, if you can but compass a Maiden-head, though but your Taylor's Daughter's, you have setled a reputation for ever. Why, Sir, there are Maiden-heads among the Women of Quality, though not so many perhaps; but there are favours of all kinds to be had among 'em; As easily brought about, and at the same price of pains that you can purchase a Chamber-maids.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'm glad you tell me so.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why there's Mrs. New-love and her Cozen Tru-game, Mrs. Artist, Mrs. Dancer, Lady Smirket, Lady Woudmore; and twenty more of your Acquaintance and mine, all very fine Women to the Eye—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And of Reputation to the World.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why those very Women of Reputation to the World have every one of 'em, to my certain knowlege, an entrigue upon their hands, at this very time; for I'm intimate with all of 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I see you are.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: But, as fine as they seem to the Eye, Mr. Wilding, what with the false complexions of their Skins, their Hair and Eye-brows; with other defects about e'm, which I must not discover of my friends, you know; with their stinking breath in the morning, and other unsavory smells all the day after, they are most of them intolerable to any Man that has the use of his Nose.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: That I cou'd not believe indeed, but that you tell me so.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Then there's Mrs. Faceall, a very fair Woman indeed, and a great Fortune: as much in shape as you see her, I have been a God mother to two of her Children, and she passes for a very good Maid still.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She past upon me I assure you; for I was very near marrying her my self once.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Chuse where you please, but I wou'd not advise you to any I have nam'd yet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Is there any hopes of Mrs. Friend-all?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Little, or none, yet a while, I believe: Mr. Love-more has at present engaged her: But there's my Cozen Slightly! Lord, that I shou'd forget her so long! That I shou'd be so backward in serving a friend! She is the fittest Woman in the World for you; the most convenient for your purpose, in all the Town; easie in her humour and fortune, and able to make her Lover so every way: She shall be the Woman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Wou'd you wou'd make her so.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I can and will make her so. We shall walk in the Mall this Morning, if you think fit to be there, it may introduce the acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'll but but dress, and be with you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I don't doubt, but in a little time, to give you an opportunity, and the Lady an inclination of having it improved, but that must be your business; I'm a going about mine, to make her a Visit. Remember our bargain, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I warrant you:
Let Whore-masters rejoice; the times must mend,
If every Woman has but such a friend.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A Gentleman to speak with me!
I am gon to Banstead-downs, to the Horse-match.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There's no Match there, Sir, this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Not this fortnight! I had forgot my self: But you may say, I went out by five in the morning; and you don't know when I come back. Go, tell him so.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I have told him already, you were within, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Pox on him, what manner of man is he? Does he look like a man of business?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Not much like a man of business.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: No, I warrant you; some Coxcombly Companion or other, that visits in a morning; and makes other People idle, not to be idle himself. But can't you tell what he wou'd have with me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I'll ask him, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: He may be a Messenger for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I'll bring an account of him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wou'd he were a Messenger: I cou'd be contented to pay the fees, to be secur'd in the hands of the Government for a fortnight. Well, This guilt is certainly very terrible. The Blow I gave Friendall was a very ill thing done of me; It lies heavier upon my Conscience this morning, than it did upon his Face last night.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: His name is Captain Springam: You know his business, he says.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I guess at it: I thought what it wou'd come to.
Show him up to me.
I must do as well as I can.
sp.p: There comes no good of being too forward upon these occasions— 'twill require some Time to dress agen: 'tis Gaming-time at least.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Good Morrow, Sir, I have a small Bill upon you here.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A Challenge I suppose.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Payable at sight, as you will find it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: You take me unprovided, you see, Sir, to answer you at sight.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Ile stay till you dress, Sir, if that be all, to have you along with me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, I'll go along with you; never doubt it Sir; you shan't stay long for me; I may dress time enuff for some Body, if that be your business: I'll do the Gentleman reason, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: We ask no more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: You are his Friend I suppose?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: At your Friends Service: I serve upon these occasions sometimes, by way of second, or so, when I want employment of my own.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Is fighting your Employment?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: 'Tis a Soldiers Employment.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, I beg your pardon, I'm sorry I must disappoint you; I never make use of a second; especially in such a Quarrel, as this is; where I am so much in the wrong already, that I am almost unwilling to engage in it any farther my self: Where is your Friend, pray?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Below, in a Coach, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: O dear, Sir, don't let him wait upon me, bring him up, I beseech you— and d'ye hear Sir? I'm loath to justifie an ill thing, if he is resolved to be satisfied, why with all my heart, Sir, I'll give him the Satisfaction of a Gentleman, I'll beg his pardon; pray tell him so.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: If fighting be his Employment, wou'd he were at it, any where else, and I fairly rid of him: I cou'd discover now that Lovemore set me on to affront him; that wou'd throw the Quarrel upon Lovemore: But then Lovemore knows me, and I must expect to be scurvily us'd by him if I do: Hang baseness; 'tis but begging pardon at last.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: A very Civil Gentleman, Brother,
He is not the Man you took him for.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: No, indeed, Sir, the Captain's in the right; I never justifie an ill thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis very well you don't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I am more a Man of Honour, I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I shall be glad to find you so.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sir you shall find me so; I scorn to do an ill thing, as much as any Man: I was last Night in the wrong, as every Man is sometimes; and I'm sorry for't: what would you have more Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: That is is not enough, Sir, I must have more.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Why, I beg your Pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: What's begging my Pardon, Sir, for such a Publick Asfront?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: So, now he grows upon him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: That won't do my business, begging my pardon: My Reputation's at Stake, and that must be satisfied, before you and I part Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you are the strangest Man in the World; You won't oblige me to justifie an ill thing, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Damme, Sir, what do you mean? Not to give me satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, to give you any satisfaction, in reason; But I can't fight against my Conscience, if I were to be hang'd, Sir, not I.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: No, Brother, that's a little too hard upon the Gentleman: You see his Conscience won't suffer him to fight with you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Dam him and his Conscience; he made no Conscience of affronting me.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: But his Conscience has flown in his Face since, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: And now he finds it only in his fears.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Come, come, you may be satisfied without fighting.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: If you think so Brother—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Pox on't, they'r here before me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Captain, I'll beg your Friends pardon, in any publick Place, at the Musick Meeting, if he pleases—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: That's staying too long for't.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or in full Mall, before the Beau's, or the Officers of the Guard; or at Will's Coffee-House before the Witts, or in the Play-House, in the Pitt, before the Vizard Masks, and Orange-Wenches; or behind the Scenes, he fore the Women-Actors; or any where else, but upon the Stage; and you know, one wou'd not willingly be a Jest to the upper Galleries.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: You hear what he says, Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'll do you Justice. Sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: If none of these offers will serve his Turn, Sir, if your Friend will be satisfied with nothing but Extremities; let him look to himself, let what will be the Consequence; I must do as well as I can with him.
sp.stage: Seeing Lovemore he takes heart again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: So, he has seen me, I find.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: What the Devil he won't fight at last sure.

sp.speaker: Ruff
sp.p: Sir, your most humble Servant You guess these Gentlemens business I suppose: I have offer'd 'em any satisfaction, in reason: But taking me, as you see, Sir, at a Disadvantage, two to one, nothing wou'd content 'em, without exposing my self, as a Rascal, to all the Town, Sir; now Sir, you are more a Gentleman I know, and they shall be damn'd, before I give 'em any other satisfaction, now I have a Man of Honour to stand by me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Gentlemen I came to reconcile you, if I can: what say you?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: He offer'd just now to beg my Brother's Pardon in the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Make your best on't; I did so.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Then let it be to Night in the Side-box, before the Ladies.—

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: For they are the Part of the Town, that a Man of Pleasure should secure a Reputation withal. Your Servant Sir. Lovemore, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: And hast thou begg'd his Pardon?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And glad to come off so: I was never so put to't, to bring my self off a Quarrel before, it had been impossible, if the Captain had not done a good Office between us, but I bore up as soon as I saw you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But then 'twas too late. You had sneakingly begg'd his Pardon be-before: if you had sent to me at first, I wou'd have brought you off cleverly: Suppose he had carry'd you behind Southampton house, which he never intended, 'twas but falling down, or dopping your Sword, when you came there, to have sav'd all: but now you have ruin'd your own Reputation, and my Design upon him for ever.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What cou'd I do? he not only sent me a Challenge, but came himself to carry me along with him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How? send you a Challenge, and come with it himself! That's something odd; pray, let's see the Challenge.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: There 'tis; make your best on't; the Paper will make admirable Crackers for a Lord. Major's Show, every word in't is as hot as Gun-powder, I'm glad I'm rid on't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If this be Friendall's Stile, 'tis mightily mended of late: I have a Note of his about me, upon Child, for money, won at play: I'll compare 'em.— 'Tis not his hand neither— Nay then there's more in't— This may be a Stratagem of his Wifes— I've seen her hand, and think this very near it: It must be so: But then Friendall's coming for Satisfaction, is an Argument he might send this Challenge: But coming at the same time, with it himself, is an Argument against him, that he knew nothing of the matter. For tho' he delivers his Love-Letters, he wou'd hardly deliver his Challenges himself: And for his coming here, Springam might put him upon't, from a reasonable Probability, that this Fellow was a Rascal. I don't know what to fix upon: This Challenge will be of use to me, with the Lady: I'll take it for granted, that she writ it, and proceed upon it accordingly.

div.stage: [Mr. Friendall, Springam, with Mrs. Friendall, and Mrs. Teazall.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: Brother, if you have no farther Service for me, I must think of employing my self, my Walk lies another way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: I'm glad you'r rid of this Business so handsomely, Mr. Friendall, and that Mr. Lovemore was by, at his begging your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
