sp.p: When I undertake things of this kind, I always go thro' with 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: This is very well over, and I hope, you will take care to keep out of 'em for the future.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Every man has the misfortune of 'em sometimes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: But 'tis a prudent Man's part, to keep out of the occasion of 'em: And, in order to't, Mr. Friendall, I cou'd wish, you wou'd not make your House, as you daily do, one of the publick Places of the Town.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: She's in the right on't indeed, Mr. Friendall, you are very happy in the Discretion of a good Lady, if you know when you'r well; there are very few Women wou'd quarrel with your good Nature, in this Point, Sir; But she has too great a regard to her own, and your Reputation, you see, not to apprehend the Malice of ill Tongues, upon the Liberties you allow in your Family, the graver part of your Friends take notice of it already, and let me tell you, Sir, are extremely concern'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p:
That they are past the pleasures of good Company themselves: Why really, Madam, I believe it: But they may say what they will, I shall do what I please: I live to my self, and not to the whimsical Humour of the graver part
of my friends, and so you may tell 'em, good Madam, from your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: You won't leave us, Mr. Friendall?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: I'le go home with you, like a good Husband, Madam; but no man of fashion, you know, walks with his Wife; besides, there's a Noble Lord I must walk with.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Any thing to be rid of my Company.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Why, how have the men, at this rate, the impudence to think the Women shou'd not Cuckold 'em! if I had such a Husband, as old as I am, a'my Conscience, I believe, I shou'd use him as he deserved: But that's some comfort, use him as you please, no Body will think you wrong him; and let me tell you, 'tis a great thing to have the Town on ones side.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I'le keep 'em so, if I can.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Nay, Faith and Troth, you have given him fair warning; if he won't take it, he must answer himself for all the miscarriages you can be guilty of, in your Conduct hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: There's something more in that Mrs. Teazall.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: There's your Mrs. Friendall before us: I honour her Character as much as I despise her Husbands.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Tho' he has scap'd the publick discovery, if he knows him to be a Coward, it does my business still as well.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: If I did not think him one, I wou'd put him to a tryal, he shou'd not so easily get clear off; for putting a Note into Mrs. Slightly's hand at the Musick-meeting.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: But I owe him a good turn for it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It comes into my head, and you shall pay him the good turn: What if you put Mrs. Sightly upon telling his Wife of it?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You ought to do it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I think so too my self; and you may be satisfied I'le do't; more out of a regard to the Women I value so much, than any design of promoting your Cuckolding the Fool.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Good grave Sir, the Plot is never the worse, I hope, for carrying your Friends interest along with the Ladys.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Make your best use on't, Lovemore; I'm contented you shou'd thrive together.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: You are mightily injur'd indeed, Madam, to be persuaded to come abroad, so much to your disadvantage, such a delicate Morning, as this is, so much against your inclinations: But you'l know your int'rest better, in a little time, and me for your friend, I suppose, when you find the benefit of it.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Nay, Cozen, the Injury may be forgiven, for the pleasure of the walk, at this time of the Year.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
Why, the very walk is to be lik'd, tho' there were no Body in it to like us: But there's a great deal of good Company in the Mall, and, I warrant you, we'll have our share of the Commendation of the place, in spight of
fresher Faces: You are sure of your part of it already.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: How so, good Mrs. Wittwoud?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Why, good Mrs. Sightly, there's Mr. Wellvile before you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: My Platonick Lover as you call him.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: And as you find him.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I think him very much my Friend.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Very much your Friend! I grant you indeed, every Woman, that is not wholly insensible, (and one wou'd not be thought insensible you know,) every Woman ought to have a Platonick Passion for one Man or other: But a Platonick Lover in a Man! is—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: What pray?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why, he is a very unmannerly Fellow; he is not what he shou'd be; that's certain: As for the matter of Respect, which we keep such a clutter about, and seem to value so much in the Men, all that I know of it, is, that if any Man pretended to follow and like me, I shou'd never believe what he said; if he did not do something to convince me, I shoud think he affronted me extreamly; if upon the first handsome occasion, he did not offer me every thing in his power.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: How Cozen!

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I hate a Blockhead, that will never give a Woman a reputable occasion of refusing him: 'Tis one of the best Complements a Lover can make his Mistresses pride and I never knew any man, that did his business without it.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Why Wittwoud, thou art Mad sure.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And for your Mr. Wellvile, if I were in your place, I shou'd have something the better opinion of him, if he wou'd have a little worse opinion of me: But between you and me, I shou'd not like him for a Lover.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: He does not pretend to be one.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Who's here? Wilding and Courtall behind us? That Wilding, Cozen, is a very pretty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: And Courtall too, very well.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I must bring you acquainted with Wilding.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: No more acquaintance, good Wittwoud.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: For his Discretion, and Conduct, his good Behaviour, and all that, Wellvile is his acquaintance, and will answer for: But his agreeable, easie Wit, and good Humor, you may take upon my word: You'l thank me, when you know him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She's a Woman of her word: You see she has brought Mrs. Sightly along with her.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I never doubted it: She'l carry her to Supper in a Night or two: She's never the worse Bawd, I hope, for being a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A good Family indeed gives a countenance to the profession; and a Reputation is necessary to carry on the Credit of a Trade.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Here's Wellvile just behind us.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Prithee stay with him: I'le tell you how I thrive.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Good Morrow Mr. Courtall.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: O Sir, yours.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Was not that Wilding left you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: He's in his Employment, Sir, very busie.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: In pursuit of the Women I know: It hardly answers the Expence I doubt.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You have no reason to say so: There's a Lady before us, of your acquaintance, Mrs. Sightly by Name, of another opinion: I suppose, she thinks such an assurance, as his, in coming to the point, is more to the nature of the thing, than all your Ceremony and Respect.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Mrs. Sightly!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She, Sir, the very same: I cou'd tell you a Secret, Wellvile; but you are one of those Fellows, that hate another Man shou'd lie with a Woman, tho' you never attempt her your self: I confess I am something of your mind: I think the enjoyment the dull part of an Intrigue, and therefore I give it over, when I see the Lady in earnest.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: But the Secret Courtall.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why Faith, Wellvile, if you have temper to manage it, the Secret may be of use to you: Wilding, you know, never Debauches a Woman, only for himself; where he visits, in a little time, every Man may be received in his turn. You must know, 'twas Wittwoud put him upon Mrs. Sightly, she knew what she did I suppose, and has promised him a good Office, in her way: make your advantage of what I tell you; but not a Syllable to any one.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: O Courtall! here are a Couple of Vizard-masks have set upon me in the next Walk, and I wanted thee to take one of 'em off my hands.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I'le stand by you, my Noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: (solus) I'll think no more on't, 'tis impossible: what's impossible? nothing's impossible to a Woman: we judge but on the outside of that Sex; and know not what they can, nor what they doe, more than they please to shew us. I have known Mrs. Sightly these seven years— known her! I mean, I have seen her, observed her, followed her: may be there's no knowing a Woman: but in all that time, I never found a freedom, that allowed me any encouragement beyond a friend— May be I have been wanting to my self—. But then she would not throw her self away upon a common Lover; that's not probable: If she had been affectedly reserv'd, I wou'd suspect, the Devil in her heart had stampt the sign of Vertue in her looks, that she might cheat the world, and sin more close. But she is open in her carriage, easie, clear of those arts that have made Lust a Trade— Perhaps that openness may be design— 'Tis easie to raise doubts— And still she may be— I won't think she can— till I know more: But Wittwoud is, I know her, every thing that's mischievous; abandon'd and undone; undone her self, she wou'd undo the Sex: she is to bawd for Wilding: I know her bad enough for any trade. But Bawds have some good Nature, and procure pleasure for pay: Wittwoud has baser ends, A general ruine upon all her friends.
sp.stage: Several pass over the Stage, Mr. Friendall slighted by 'em, one after another.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord,
sp.p: I have a little business at present; But I shall see you at the Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: In the King's Box, my Lord.—
My Dear Lord, I'm your humble Servant

sp.speaker: 2. Lord,
sp.p: Another time, Good Mr. Friendall; You see I'm engag'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: A Pox o'their Engagements: A Man can't make one among 'em O my most noble Lord.

sp.speaker: 3. Lord,
sp.p: I know you will upbraid me, Mr. Friendall; But I'll recover your opinion, and come and dine with you. Let's have Jack Dreyden and Will. Wicherly, as you call'em: Some of these days, we'll be very witty together: But now I am your Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: This is a very unfortunate Morning with me: I have not walkt one turn with a Lord, since I came in: I see I must take up with the men of wit to day— O Mr. Wellvile!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Don't let me keep you from better Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I prefer a Man of Wit, to a Man of Quality at any time.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: If she thinks Wittwoud her friend, after this, 'tis a sign she's pleas'd with with it, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Why, Wellvile, thou art cogitabund, as a man may say; thy head is running upon thy Poetry.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I beg your pardon. Sir, I did not mind you indeed.
Your Servant, Mr. Wilding———

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Wilding, Yours. But Wellvile, Prithee, what is't to be? A Song? a Tribue to the whole Sex? or, a particular Sacrifice? or, is't a Libel upon the Court, ha? (we'll keep your council;) or, a Lampoon upon the Town? What, I am a great Honourer, and humble Servant of the Muses my self—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: A very Favourite of 'em, I hear Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: I sometimes scribble indeed, for my diversion—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And the diversion of the Ladys, Mr. Friend-all—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And the diversion of all the Town, Mr. Friend-all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Why, Faith Gentlemen, Poetry is a very pretty Amusement, and, in the way of Intrigue, or so, among the better rank of people, I have known a Paper of Verses go farther with a Lady in the purchase of a Favour, than a Present of fifty pounds wou'd have done.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: O, Sir, 'tis the only way of purchasing a Woman that is not to be bought.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: But, Wellvile, prithee communicate, Man.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Why, if you will have it, I have a design upon a Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Gad so, let me write a Scene in it: I have a thousand times had it in my head, but never cou'd bring it about to write a Play yet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No; no; You had it not in your head, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: I vow to Gad, but I have then, twenty times, I'm confident; but one thing or other always kickt it out again: But I promise you, I'll write a Scene for you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Before you know the Subject?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Prithee, what is't? But be what it will; Here's my hand upon't; I'll write it for you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
You must know then, Sir, I am scandaliz'd extremely to see the Women upon the Stage make Cuckolds at that insatiable rate they do in all our modern Comedies: without any other reason from the Poets, but, because a man is married he must be a Cuckold: Now, Sir, I think, the Women are most unconscionably injur'd by this general Scandal upon their Sex; therefore to do
'em what service I can in their vindication, I design to write a Play, and call it—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Ay, what, I beseech you, I love to know the Name of a new Play.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: The Wives Excuse, or, Cuckolds make themselves.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: A very pretty Name faith and troth; and very like to be popular among the Women.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And true among the Men.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: But what Characters have you?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What Characters? Why I design to shew a fine young Woman marry'd to an impertinent, nonsensical, silly, entrigueing, cowardly, good for-nothing Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: This Blockhead does not know his own Picture.

sp.speaker: Mr Fr.
sp.l: Well, and how? She must make him a Cuckold I suppose.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Twas that I was thinking on when you came to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: O, Yes, You must make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: By all means a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: For such a Character, Gentlemen, will vindicate a Wise in any thing she can doe to him. He must be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am satisfied he ought to be a Cuckold; and indeed, if the Lady wou'd take my advice, she shou'd make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: She'll hear reason I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I have not yet determin'd how to dispose of her. But in regard to the Ladies, I believe I shall make her honest at last.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: I think the Ladies ought to take it very ill of you, if you do: But if she proves honest to the last, that's certain, 'tis more than the fellow deserves. A very pretty Character this, faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And very well known in this Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Gad, I believe, I can help you to a great many hints, that may be very serviceable to you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I design to make use of you: We, who write Plays, must sometimes be beholden to our friends. But more of this at leisure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Will you walk, Gentlemen, the Ladies are before us.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I have a little business with Wilding. We'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Business with me, Wellvile?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: About a fair Lady, I'll tell you as we walk.
sp.stage: Enter Lovemore with Mrs. Friendall, Mrs. Sightly, Mrs. Wittwoud, and Mrs. Teazall.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, Mr. Lovemore, as matters are manag'd between the men and women of the Town, 'tis no less a blessing for a Lady to have a Husband that will but so much as offer to fight for her and her honour, than 'tis for a Husband to have a Lady, that has any honour to defend: There's such a depravity in Matrimony, o' both sides, now-a-days.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Why, good Madam, is it such a business, for a Man to offer to fight for his Wife?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: All that I know is, the Man that wou'd not fight for me, shou'd do nothing else for me.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: You'll have your witt, let who's will blush for't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
As you say, Madam, (to Mrs. Teazall) A Man of honour is a great blessing in a Husband; such as Mr. Friendall has shown himself to be. And
here's a Lady will value the blessing as it deserves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I must indeed, despise him in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Fulsome and foolish! let's hear no more on't: They don't think this can blind us:

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If you were not inclin'd to it before, Madam, this last behaviour of his wou'd engage you to value such a blessing as you ought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: My duty wou'd engage me— What does he mean by this?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Cozen Teazall, your opinion pray.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have something to tell you, Madam, if you wou'd but allow me; this is no place.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: You'll find a time I warrant you. Ladies the Mall begins to thin.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you declare your self in love with the Lady, and I am not, I promise you, and you may trust me, I'll never follow her more.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I do trust, and thank you for the promise. Ladies your Servant.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: O! he's come at last.
sp.p: There's nothing to be done here; You've outstay'd your time; But we'll call at the Chocalate-house in St. Alban-street, as we go home; You may meet us there by accident, you know.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If I were to be hang'd now, I must meet 'em there; though I have given my word to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Is that the filthy fellow?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: That's Wilding, Madam.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: I see there's no knowing a Whore master by his Face; He looks like a modest, civil Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Your friend, Mrs. Wittwoud, Madam, may be of (to Sightly) that good natur'd opinion that Lovemore is familiar with the Husband, only to be more familar with the Wife. But you must be cautious of what you say; for fear we turn the Scandal upon you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Upon me, Mrs. Wellvile?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I have the freedom of a friend: But Mr. Friendall declares he is in love with you; And after that, the good natur'd Town (whatever they believe) will go near to say, that your familiarity with his Wife may be in order to the Husband.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Contemptible! Sure no-body wou'd think so.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Tis an ill natur'd Age to handsome women, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Must I suffer, because he's a Fool?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You may suffer, because he's a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: This is not only to be accountable for our own conduct, but to answer for all the indiscretion of the Mens.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You must, Madam, for those Mens you allow to be so near you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: It wou'd be but an ungratefull piece of News to Mrs. Friendall, if I should be serious enough to tell her of it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be more ungratefull to her, if any body else did; and wou'd go near to make you serious, if another should tell her for you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: But who can tell? It may be the cause of a breach between 'em.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, if it be considerable enough to make a breach in Marriage; You may be sure 'twill make a breach in Friendship: And how much that will be to the advantage of your reputation upon such an occasion—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I am convinc'd you are my friend, Mr. Wellvile, And thank you for this care of me.
sp.stage: They mingle with Lovemore, Mrs. Friendall, & the rest.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: This is the Aunt wou'd ha' been upon your bones, I assure you, if I had not deliver'd you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How shall I do to appease her?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: There's but one way now to please her. You must know she has been in her time; like other women, in at most of the pleasures of this Town; But being too passionate a Lover of the Sport, she has been,——, a Bubble at all Games: And having now nothing to lose but her money, she declares for Lanterelow, and is contented to be only cheated at Cards.

sp.stage: Mr. Friendall with Springam and Courtall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Why, what do you think, Ladies? these Gentlemen here, in spight of the temptation of so, much good Company, refuse to dine with me.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: O Madam! Are you there?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Your Brother has seduced me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: We'll visit you at Night, Ladies, in Masquerade; when the privilege of a Vizard will allow us a Conversation, out of your forms, and more to our humour a great deal, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Lovemore, Wellvile, Wilding,— You'll follow us?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: We won't fail you, Sir.
sp.stage: [Mr. Friendall goes out with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: St. Albans street——

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: We'll tell you more of this.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Wilding, you'll take another turn with us?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith no, I'm tir'd: we shall meet at Friendall's all.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: At Friendall's be it then;
Where the kind Husband wellcomes every Guest.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: He but invites, his Wife must make the Feast.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: All the Company enters after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: MR. Friendall, You have the best Wines, and the greatest choice of any man in Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: There's an elegance in Eating and Drinking, Gentlemen, as well as in Writing.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Or your style wou'd never go down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: How did you like the Lucina I gave you, the Galicia, the Mountain-Alicant? You taste the Sun in them perfectly, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: O, plainly, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p:
Then the Aracina, the Ranchio, and the Peralta, the Carcavelis, the Lacrymae, the Schiveas, the Zephalonia, the Montalchyno, with all the Muschatellos,
and to conclude, my single Bottle of Tockay.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Admirable all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: A Friend of mine, that brought the Tockay from Buda, assures me, the stones of all those Grapes are Gold.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: That makes the Wine so scarce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Nay, not unlikely: But of all the Wines of all the Climates under the Sun—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Give me the Greek.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: O, I abominate—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: The Language, but not the Wines; you may relish them without it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Ay, that may be: But of all the Wines, Pagan, or Christian, in the World, I think the Borachio the Noblest.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: 'Tis of the roughest kind indeed of Beasts, wou'd he were in the Skin of one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: But your Vine de Congress, Mr. Friendall—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: True; but 'tis a Dutch Wine, and grows in the Province of Zealand, I have drank it upon the place.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But, Mr. Friendall, pray in all your variety and interest among your Friends in the City, have you not sometimes met with such a Wine, as the Vine de Short-Neck?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Vine de Short-Neck? Yes, I have drank of it at Thompson's, and was the first that took notice of it; but 'tis a Prohibited French Wine, and I have too great an Acquaintance with the Members of Parliament, not to Drink according to Law.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Yours is very good Snuff, Mr. Friendall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Yes, truly, I think 'tis pretty good Powder.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Pray your Opinion of mine, you are a Critick.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: This is Havanna indeed; but then 'tis wash'd: Give me your dry Powders, they never lose their Scent: Besides, yours is made of the Leaves of the Tobacco—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Why, what the Devil's yours?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Mine, Sir, is right Palillio, made of the Fibres, the Spirituous part of the Plant; there's not a pinch of it out of my Box in England; 'twas made I assure you to the Pallat of His Most Catholick Majesty, and sent me by a great Don of Spain, that's in his Prince's particular Pleasures.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And his, it seems, lie in his Nose.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Ladies what say you to the Fresko of the Garden? we'll Drink our Tea upon the Mount, and be the Envy of the Neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Wittw.
sp.l: O delicately thought upon!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Madam, which Tea shall we have?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Which the Company pleases, Mr. Friendall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: The plain Canton, the Nanquin, the Bohe, the Latheroon, the Sunloe, or which? Ha!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Have you any of the Non Amo Te?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Faith, No, Sir, there came but little of it over this Year; but I am promis'd a whole Canister by a Friend of a considerable interest in the Committee.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Then the Bohe, Sir, the Bohe will do our business.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: My Bohe, at the best hand too, Cost me Ten Pound a Pound, but I have a Tea, with a damn'd Heathenish hard Name, that I think I was very much befriended in, at an Indian House in the City, if you please, we'll have some of that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: 'Tis in my Cabinet, Mr. Friendall, I must order it my self for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: That Madam must make the Complement the greater to the Company: Allons, you know the way, I wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This way she must come, she can't avoid me, thanks to the honest Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Are you one of the Gentlemen that love the Tea with a hard Name?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I must love any thing that gives me an Opportunity—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: With any Woman that has a mind to improve it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Of Adoring you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Me, Mr. Lovemore! I was going before, but now you drive me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Stay, this Violence, if you can call it Violence on my Knees, excuses you to all your Female Forms; nay, to your self, severer than your Forms, if you should stay and hear me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Well, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Every thing is matter of your Praise, the subject of fresh wonder: your Beauty made to tire the Painter's Art, your Wit to strike the Poet's Envy dumb.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Are you turn'd Poet too?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Indeed you can inspire me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: With the Spirit of Scandal I may, a small matter Conjures up a Lampoon against the Women— But to the purpose, Sir, you pretend business with me, and have insinuated a great deal of pains all this Day to get an occasion of speaking to me in private; which now, by Mr. Friendall's assistance, you think you have ingeniously secur'd: Why, Sir, after all, I know no business between us that is to be carried on, by my being alone with you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'm sorry for that indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Suppose, Mr. Lovemore, a Man shou'd hit you a Box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Only suppose it, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Why, Sir, any man that's Brute enough may do it, tho' that Brute shou'd beg your Pardon never so publickly for the wrong, you wou'd never heartily forgive him, for pitching upon you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Not heartily I believe indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Why, very well: You keep me here against my Will, against all Rules of Decency, to me, my Sex, and Character; the worst of Wrongs; yet you will think it hard to be Condemn'd, or Hated for your Light Opinion of me, that first encourag'd you to this design.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Hated for Loving you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p:
Ay, there's the business: Who wou'd not stay to see her Worshipper upon his Knees, thus Prais'd, and thus Ador'd? Her Beauty made to tire the Painter's Art, her Wit to strike the Poet's Envy dumb; and all deliver'd in such
a dying tone, no Lady can out-live it. Mr. Lovemore, you might have known me better, than to imagine your fly Flattery, and softly Sing me into a Consent to any thing my Virtue had abhorr'd. But how have I behav'd my self? What have I done to deserve this? What encouragement have I giv'n you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A Lover makes his Hopes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Perhaps 'tis from the general encouragement of being a Marry'd Woman, supported on your side by that Honourable Opinion of our Sex, that, because some Women Abuse their Husbands, every Woman may. I grant you indeed, the Custom of England has been very prevailing in that point; and I must own to you, an ill Husband is a great provocation to a Wife, when she has a mind to believe as ill of him as she can

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: How if the Wife believe too well of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Why then the Folly's hers: For my part, I have known Mr. Friendall too long, not to know justly what he deserves; I won't justifie his Faults, but because he does not take that care of me he shou'd, must not I have that regard to my self I ought? What I do is for my own sake: Nay what is past, which, by your hints, I know you do suspect, I own I did it; not for the Commendation of your Wit, nor as a Debt to him, but to my self, foreseeing a long Life of Infamy, which in his Follies I was Marry'd to; and therefore sav'd my self by saving him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Conduct every where is excellent, but there it was a Master-piece indeed, and worthy Admiration.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: And wou'd you have me lose that Character, so worthy Admiration, which, ev'n you, an Enemy, must praise, when you wou'd ruin? No, what I've done to raise this Character, may be an Argument I will do more to heighten it, to the last Act of Life.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And all for the reward of being thought too good a Wife to such a Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: How! you know him then?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You and I know him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Fit to bear a wrong? Is that the reason of your wronging him? I want but that; O let me but believe you injure him, because you know you may; and attempt me, because you think it safe; and I will scorn you low, as you do him: You say you know him: Now, Sir, I know you, you, and your Practices, against us both: You have encourag'd all that has been done, exposing him, only to ruin me. 'Tis necessary to believe as ill of you as I can: And for the future, till you clear your self—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I can clear my self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: I le think you capable of every thing; of any baseness to advance your ends; so leave you to your Triumph.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam stay, I must be Justified: This Challenge here has taught me all I know; made me suspect who writ it, and presume all I have said to you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Where had you it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Russle gave it me. I hope you may forgive my knowing it, since by resigning it into your hands, I give you up the only evidence, that can rise up against him: Such a piece of News, Madam, wou'd have been welcome enough to the ill nature of the Town; and I might have had my ends in such a report, had I encourag'd the exposing him: But when I saw how near you
were concern'd, I had no other pleasure, but the thought of serving you; if I have served you, I am over-paid, if not, I must serve on. For I but live to serve you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: My employment calls upon me; Are not you for Tea?
sp.stage: Two Footmen with a Service of Tea enter, and go out with Mrs. Friendall.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I find I am restor'd, but I was reduc'd to the necessity of a lye to come into favour again; but that's a Necessity that every man of honour must submit to, sometimes, that has any thing to manage with the women: For a Lover, that never speaks more than the truth, is never believed to be a Lover: and he that won't lye to his Mistress, will hardly lye with her: So let his Honesty reward him; the Lady won't, I dare say for her. There must be a cheat upon the sense sometimes, to make a perfect pleasure to the soul: For if the women did but always know what really we are; we shou'd not so often know so much of them as we doe: But 'tis their own faults; they know we can't live without 'em, and therefore ask more of us than we have honestly to give for the purchase. So, very often, they put us upon dissimulation, slattery and false love, to come up to their price. Mrs. Friendall went away a little abruptly: I'm glad she did: for that methinks confesses an obligation which she has not yet in her power to return.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Lovemore, your Plot begins to thrive: I left Mrs. Sightly telling Mrs. Friendall every thing between her and Mr. Friendall: I thought fit to acquaint you with it, that you might be prepared: You know best what use to turn it to: my business is with Mrs. Sightly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I thank you for the News: they'r coming this way, I wou'd not have 'em see us: I must hover here.
sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Friendall and Mrs. Sightly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I cou'd not have believ'd it.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I am sorry you have reason to believe it upon my account: indeed, I was unwilling to believe it; I suffered it as long as I cou'd; but finding no end of this persecution—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: You have us'd me like a friend, and I thank you— his Note since Dinner, desires you wou'd meet him at 7, at Rosamond's pond: You can't be so hard hearted to disappoint him?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: If you have a mind to have a plainner proof of his treachery—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: The proof is plain enough: You say it: Besides, he has giv'n it under his hand here; And I believe the Gentleman, though you won't.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Or if you wou'd, let him know you have discover'd him, and upbraid him with his baseness before me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: That wou'd but harden him, or make him vain, By shewing a concern for him.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: If you have any curiosity to be satisfied, I'll go with you to the place appointed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I wou'd not have him know either of us.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Then we must have a man to secure us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: We may trust your friend Mr. Wellvile.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Mr. Friendall, you must know, thinks him in love with me; So being a Rival, may make him avoid us: But Mr. Lovemore will do as well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I wou'd not have him know it.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: He knows it already; I made no secret of it, and Mr. Wellvile told it him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Then he, or any one—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: O! here he comes: Mr. Lovemore, we must employ you this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: To serve my self, in waiting upon you.
sp.stage: The rest of the Company enter to 'em.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Well, here's such a Clutter to get you to Cards: You have drank your Tea: what will you do next, I trow?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why take a Napp, or smoak a Pipe, any body that has a mind to be private.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Wou'd I had one civilly in a Corner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Get the Cards in the Drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Not till we have the Song, Mr. Friendall, you promis'd us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Why, faith, I was forc'd to set it my self: I don't know how you'll like it with my voice; but faith and troth, I believe the Masters of the Musick-meeting, may set their own words, for any trouble I shall give 'em for the future about mine.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, then you ruine 'em.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: The Song, the Song, Sir.
sp.stage: [Song written by a Man of Quality.]

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Say, cruell Amoret, how long
In billet-dous, and humble Song,
Shall poor Alexis woo?
If neither writing, sighing, dying,
Reduce you to a soft complying:
O! when will you come to?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Full thirteen Moons are now past o'er,
Since first those Stars I did adore,
That set my heart on fire:
The conscious Play-house, Parks and Court,
Have seen my sufferings made your sport:
Yet am I ne'er the nigher.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: A faithfull Lover shou'd deserve
A better fate, than thus to starve
In sight of such a Feast:
But Oh! if you'll not think it fit,
Your hungry Slave shou'd taste one bit;
Give some kind looks at least.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Admirable well—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Sett and sung, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A Gentleman does these things always best.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: When he has a Genius.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, he must have a Genius: There's no being a Master of any thing without a Genius.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Mrs. Teazall Pam wants you in the next room.
sp.stage: Scene draws, shews Tables and Cards.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: I'll make the more of him, when I get him into my hands.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I have something to tell you, worth more than the Cards can win for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Who's for Comet?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I am your Man Madam

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: You play too deep for me.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Cozen, you'll make one of us?
sp.stage: They go in to play. The Scene shut's upon 'em, Wellvile and Sightly stay.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I go your halves, if you please, I don't care for playing my self.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Wellvile, you have something extraordinary to say to me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I have, indeed, Madam, but I shou'd prepare you for the Story, there are some Friends in it, that you will be concern'd to have an ill opinion of.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I have reason to think you my Friend.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Then pray give me leave to ask, How long you have known Mr. Wilding.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I never spoke to him till this Morning, at the Chocolate-house, as we came from the Park.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I think he's Mrs. Wittwoud's particular acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: That, I suppose, gave him his Title of speaking to us.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And she has a mind to bring him acquainted with you. I'm sorry I must warn you of him: I was in hopes it wou'd have dy'd of it self: But his talking to you, at the Chocolate house, after he had promised never to follow you more, makes me apprehend, that he is still carrying on his design upon you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: A design upon me!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: He has a design upon you: And you have heard enough of his Character, to suspect the honour of any design he has upon any woman: But such as it is, your Cozen Wittwood, and very good friend, for ends of her own, which I can inform you in, has undertaken to bring it about. I see you are surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I pray, Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I never pretended to be a friend of Mrs. Wittwoud's, but now I hate her: and what I tell you, is not to ruine her with you; but of nearer consequence, to save you from being undone by her: This is not a Secret; I'll tell her of it my self; and my thoughts of her into the bargain: But, Madam, you know best, how far she has solicited his cause to you; how far my Story is probable; and whether you don't think, she persuaded you to walk this morning in the Mall, in order to Mr. Wilding: That was the business of her visit to you, as he tells me, whatever she pretended to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: You astonish me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am astonish'd my self, indeed Madam, not to find her as I always thought her, fit for any mischief: But to think she can pretend to be a Bawd, and provide no better for a friend: to sacrifice you to a Man, who wou'd tell all the Town of it, as well as Courtall, and has consessed to me, that he never was in love with you, nor had a thought that way, till she put it into his head, and promis'd to assist him in't.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Unheard of Villany!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p:
Faith, Madam, if I might advise you, it shou'd be to a Man of honour at least; that can be so tender of a reputation, not to lessen a Ladies favour so far, to make it the common mirth of the Town: if you have any favours to dispose of dispose of 'em your self: let not another run away with the benefit
of your good turns: I have been an old Admirer, Madam; and I hope stand as fair, and have as good a Title to put in my Claim, as any Man of her providing.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: So, Sir, then it seems you think I must be provided for, and therefore these Advances must please me: I have some reason to believe what you say of my Cozen Wittwoud, but I have no reason to think you very much my Friend; she has betray'd me, and you are pleased to think I deserve it: I thank you for your Caution; but it shall secure me for the future, against her and you: For as much as I thought you my Friend; nay, though I languish'd for you, the encouragement you are pleased to make, from other Peoples Base Opinion of me, shall teach me to despise you.
sp.stage: [The Scene opens, the Company rises from play, and comes forward.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I have done with you: If this be your fair play, there's no danger of your soul; why you make no Conscience of Cheating any Body out of your own Gang.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Conscience at Cards Cozen! you are a better bred Lady than to expect it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Conscience, Madam, is for serious Affairs, no Body minds it at play.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Nay I'm ev'n right enough served, I deserved it, that's the truth on't: I must be playing with Company so much younger than my self, but I shall be wiser for the future, and play the Fool in my own form, where I may Cheat in my turn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: If you speak of your Losings, Madam, I believe my Fortune has been harder than yours; in Ten Sets running with Mr. Wilding, I never turn'd one, nor had Comet in my hand.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nay, if you win her Money, you may win every thing of her, if you know how to manage your Game.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And Faith I'le play it as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Cozen, I have won an Estate for you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: You have undone me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'le watch my time, and follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Lovemore, prithee keep the Company together; I have an appointment upon my hands, and must leave you: We must serve one another sometimes, you know.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, the Jew, newly turn'd Protestant, that my Master was God-father to, has brought the Essences and Sweet-waters he order'd him to rastle for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Shall we try, whether we like any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: We shall find him a Jew still in his dealings, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You wou'd not have him lose by his Conversion, I hope.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Like other wise Men, he's for saving Soul and Body together, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Never think of denying, or excusing it to me, I am satisfied there's more in't than you ought to defend, there are so many Circumstances to convince me, of your Treachery to me, I must believe it

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I see Cozen, you will believe any thing against me: But as I hope to be sav'd, upon the Faith of a Christian, and may I never rise off my Knees into your good Opinion agen, if I don't abhor the Villany you lay to my Charge; something I must confess to you, but I beg you to forgive me, 'twas unadvis'd indeed, but innocent, and without a design upon you: Courtell's a Coxcomb, and nothing but Wilding's Vanity, or Wellvile's Revenge, cou'd be accessary to the Ruin of me with you, the only Relation I love and value in the World.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: O! I had forgot the pains you took to secure me, to Morrow Night at Cards, at your Lodgings with Mr: Wilding: Cozen, let me tell you, a Bawd is the worst part of an Intrigue, and the least to be said for't in excuse of the Infamy. But you had something more than a Lover to provide for me, or you wou'd not have expos'd me to a Man that wou'd expose me to all the Town; is it because I have been your best and last Friend, (for you will hardly find such another in your Family) that thus you reward me for the Folly? Or is it because I am a witness of your Shame, that you wou'd be a Contriver of mine? I know, (and I look upon it as a Judgment upon the former Follies of your Life,) that you are notoriously abandon'd to the Beastly Love of a Fellow, that no Body else can look upon; and, may be, you are mischievously pleas'd to make me as despicable as your self, there must be the Devil in the bottom on't, and I'le fly from him in you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: O! don't leave me in this Passion, I am utterly ruin'd if you go; upon my Knees I beg it of you.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Cozen, I forgive you; what's past shall be a Secret for both our sakes; but I'm resolv'd never more to come into your power; so farewell, and find a better Friend than I have been.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: She's lost, and my design upon her, which is yet a greater misfortune to me.

O! Sir, I am obliged to you— and you are oblig'd to your self for your success with Mrs. Sightly; so like a Boy, to discover the Secret, before 'twas in your power to expose! Away, I'le have no more to say to you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, Sir, you have made fine work on't with the Woman. I thought I had satisfied you in the Mall this Morning.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir I must be better satisfied than I was in the Morning, I find there's no relying upon your word, since, after your promise, never to follow her more, you cou'd excuse your self to me in the Mall, to meet her at the Chocolate House.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay then we have both our Grievances, and this must Answer 'em.
sp.stage: [Going to Fight, Courtall enters to part 'em.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Fie, Fie, Friends, and Fighting! that must not be Gentlemen, Mrs. Wittwoud has tole me the matter; and unless you had a Fourth Man to entertain
me, you had ev'n as good put up agen: We are all in fault, and all deserve to be swing'd for't, that's certain: Wilding was a Fool for telling me of his design, and I was a Fool for talking on't to Wellvile; and Wellvile no wiser than either, for making such a Bustle about it: Therefore pray Gentlemen let's agree in this Opinion, that by our own Prating, and prying into other Peoples Affairs, we often discover and ruin one anothers designs;
sp.l: For Women are by Nature well inclind:
Our Follies frighten 'em from being kind.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: NAy I don't wonder you thrive no better with the Women, when you can part with such an Advantage over Mrs. Friendall: You say you have won a Summ of her, which she wou'd not be known to lose: Why, another Man wou'd take the priviledg of a winning Gamester, upon such an occasion to press her to a Promise, at least, of coming out of her Debt.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I shall improve, I find, upon the advantage of your hints: But Mrs. Sightly, Madam—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Ay, Mrs Sightly indeed: Was that a Woman to throw away upon the vanity of being talk'd of for her? In the time you were bragging to other People, of being in her Favour, you might have been every where you desir'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I have made all the Excuse I could for you; some too, that in my Conscience I thought very unreasonable my self; and cou'd pass upon no Body but a Woman, that was easily dispos'd to forgive you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: If she wou'd but hear what I have to say for my self.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nay, she's pretty well prepar'd, but you must not think of speaking to her bare-fac'd, that she can't consent to for her own sake: You have made the matter so publick, she has Eyes upon her to be sure now: But it happens very luckily, Friendall has a Masq'rade to Night at his House: There, if you please, I can give you an opportunity of clearing your self to her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I Ask no more of you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Never think of defending your self, for what's past you were certainly i'th' wrong; and she thinks you so: You know well enough what to say to a Woman, that has a mind to believe you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How shall I know her at the Masq'rade?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Go, you, and prepare for't: and depend upon me for your Intelligence.

I find I am declining in my Reputation; and will bring every Woman, of my Acquaintance, into my own condition, of being suspected, at least: I have promis'd more than I can do with my Cozen Sightly; I have lost my Credit with her too lately, to betray her in the way of frendship— let me see— Betty—
You know where the Man lives, that made my Cozen Sightly's Scarf, go to him from me, desire him to borrow it, that a Lady may see it, who likes it, and desires to have one made of the same Pattern.—

I despair of bringing her to the Masquerade: I must personate her my self, and meet Wilding in her room: but what may be the Issue of that? Let what will be the Issue: the farther he presses his Design upon me, the further I carry my Design upon her: and for once, in Order to my revenge, rather than not expose her, I'll venture to grant him the favour, that he may tell on't; and she have the benefit of the Scandal—

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lovemore, with Mrs. Friendall, and Mrs. Sightly.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Yonder comes Mr. Friendall, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Wou'd I were at home agen: I came upon a foolish discovery of his Actions, to be surpris'd in a very unaccountable one of my own.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: That is, walking Incognito on this side the Park with a Man of your Character, Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I hope he won't know us.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: He's too busie in his own affairs.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: He comes upon us. I must speak to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: You are provided for, I see: The Ladies, I suppose, wish I cou'd say as much for them too: very gentile women both, faith and troth: I warrant 'em Women of Condition, if not Women of Quality, by their assignation at Rosomond's Pond.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: You fansie that from the quality of your own Entrigue.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Why there's something in that too: and the truth on't is, my assignation is with a Woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Mrs. Sightly I fansie Friendall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Fy, fy, why shou'd you think so? But let her be who she will, if she disappoint me, I'll own it to morrow to every body—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: That she disappointed you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: No; that 'twas Mrs. Sightly I had an intreigue with.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: A small matter makes an intreigue of his side, I find.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Sure I have seen some-body very like this Lady?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I would not be known for the World.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'll bring you oft, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: She has the Air and Mein very much, of a Lady of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not unlikely, faith: it may be she her self, for ought I know to the contrary: but if you have a mind to be satisfied—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Lord! what do you do?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I have no occasion for her at present: This is my Woman:
sp.p: She's but an ill-natur'd incumbrance, at this time; and you'll do me a favour to dispose of her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p:
Nay, if you are so free to dispose of her, I'm satisfy'd she is not the Woman I took her for: For, to tell you the truth, Lovemore, I thought 'twas
my Wife: And, I gad, I began to be very uneasie; not so much, for finding her in your Company; as that she shou'd come so peevishly to disturb me, in an affair, so very much above her.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Why, Sir, they say your Wife is a very fine Woman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: A Wife a fine Woman, Madam? I never knew a Husband that thought so in my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: But some body else may, Sir, if you allow her to make these Entertainments for the Town, that I hear you do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Gad so, Lovemore, prithee bring the Ladies to my Masquerade to Night; there's no body but People of Quality to be there, for pleasure is my Business, you know; and I am very well pleas'd, to allow my Wife the Liberties she takes, in favour of my own; for to tell you the Truth, the chief End of my marrying her, (next to having the Estate setled upon me) was to carry on my Entrigues more swimmingly with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: That's a Convenience in Matrimony, I did not think of:

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: One of the greatest, upon my word, Sir. For being seen so often abroad, and visiting with my Wife, I pass upon the formal part of the Town, for a very good Husband; and upon the Priviledge of that Character, I grow intimate with all her Acquaintance, (and, by the way, there's hardly a Family in Town, but I can contrive to come acquainted with, upon her account) there I pick and, and chuse in the very Face of their reverend Relations, and deliver my Billets my self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: You have 'em ready then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Two, or three, always in my Pocket:—
I write half a Dozen in a Morning, for the Service of that Day.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Hard service, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Not at all: the Letters are but Copies one of another; and a Love-letter should be a Love letter, you know, passionate, and tender, who-ever 'tis design'd for. Ha! yonder are two Women in Masks! I must not be seen with you: Ladies, you know when you'r well, I suppose, by the Choice of your Man; make much of him, he's my Bosom-friend, and Confidant of my pleasures.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: And you of his, I suppose? There's no pleasure without a Confidant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am of your mind: But Lovemore's a little too reserved, 'tis, at present, his fault, from a want of knowing the Town; but he'll mend of it, I hope, when he comes to have a Woman, worth talking of. Lovemore, not a word at home of seeing me here; as you value the Fortune of your Friend: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Are you the Confidant of the Gentleman's pleasures?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I have not betray'd 'em, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: Methinks a Friend should have warn'd me of 'em.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I wou'd not be thought to do ill Offices, especially in Marriage, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: I don't think you wou'd; wou'd Mr. Friendall were as tender of wronging me,—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: You have had a handsome Account of their Expedition: And we are both oblig'd to Mr. Friendall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: I am very well pay'd for my Curiosity of coming here: I suppose we shall have a Rendezvous of his Wenches, at the Masquerade; pray let's be ready to receive 'em.

div.head: SCENE, Mr. Friendall's House.
div.stage: Men and Women in Masquerading Habit.
Wellvile, Wilding, Courtall, Springam, Wittwood, and Betty.

sp.speaker: Wellw.
sp.p: Wilding has his Eye upon us I see: I have something to say to him, in my own Person, and then I must change Scarfs with you: Be sure you are i'th' way.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I thought I had known you;
I beg your pardon, Madam, for the mistake.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You'r very welcome to't, Sir, I wou'd have you mistaken; and that you will always be, when you judge upon the Outsides of the Women.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You are for a stricter Examination, I find: There are Conveniencies for a full Discovery, in the next room, some Body will show you the way.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's Sightly in the Scarf, and Wittwood with her, I suppose; I must not be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I like the Freedom of a Masquerade, very well; but it confounds a Man's Choice.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: Why, faith, I have a mind to be particular, if I cou'd but hitt upon the Woman.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: And that you shall presently, little Captain, I'll put my self in your way.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Behind a Cloud my pretty Moon!
Shall I be the Man in you?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: With the Bush at your Back-side: You deserve to be whipt for your Witt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: I stand corrected, Madam.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Does she beat thee, little Master? Come a' me, and I'll make much of thee——

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: As much as you can of me, I dare say for you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Come, come, I'll use you better——

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: To use me worse; is not that, your Design? She has given me my Answer at once; you perhaps wou'd linger me thro' a Winter's Expectation, and not do my Business at last—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: What's your Business pray?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: Why your Business, any Womans Business, that has a mind to employ me in't.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: No touching me: I have an unfashionable Husband in the Company, that won't thank you, for making him a Cuckold—

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: But you will, I'm sure, if it be but to teach him better manners.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: I like your Company extremely; but I have a great deal of Business, and wou'd willingly be ridd of you, at this Time; but this Ring shall answer for me, till I see you agen.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: Pray redeem it, as soon as you can.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, if you have any Interest in the Family, pray let's have a Song, or a Dance, to divert us.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.l: I'll see what I can do for you—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: You shou'd be Wilding.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And you shou'd be as good as your word.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: The Lady is better than you can expect: That's flie in the Embroider'd Scarf. You must not speak to her, before the Company, take her aside, by and by, in a Corner; She'll thank you for your care of her.
sp.l: Here's more Company:
sp.stage: Lovemore Enters with Mrs. Friendall, and Mrs. Sightly.
sp.l: I won't be seen with you—
Now Betty for the Change—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Lovemore, I am in disgrace with Mrs. Sightly: And can't find her, to come into favour agen.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That's she, that came in just now with Mrs Friendall: I'll direct you to one, by going to the other.

lg.head: A SONG, Written by Tho. Cheek Esq
lg.l: Corinna I excuse thy Face;
The erring Lines which Nature drew:
When I reflect, that every Grace
Thy Mind adorns is just, and true:
But oh! thy Witt what God has sent?
Surprizing, airy, unconfin'd:
Some wonder sure Apollo meant,
And shot himself into thy Mind.

lg.head: A SONG, In the First Scene of the Fourth Act.
lg.l: Hang this whining way of wooing,
Loving was design'd a Sport:
Sighing, talking, without doing,
Makes a silly, idle Court.
Don't believe that words can move her,
If she be not well inclin'd:
She her self must be the Lover,
To perswade her to be kind.
If, at last, she grants the favour,
And consents to be undone:
Never think her passion gave her,
To your Wishes, but her own.

sp.stage: After the Song, Wittwood and Betty, having chang'd Scarfs, Enter, to be ready for the Dance, after which——

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Some can't get Husbands, and others can't get ridd of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Every Woman carries her Cross in this World: A Husband happens to be mine, and I must bear it, as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I wou'd ease you of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: No more upon this subject, you have carried the Argument so far, 'Tis allowing what you say, to listen any longer. But Mr. Lovemore, I will give you what satisfaction I have in my power, and Praise is the reward of Vertue you know; I think you have proceeded like a Man of experience in this business, and taken the natural road to undermine most Women. I must doe you this stice, that nothing has been wanting on your side

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I wou'd have nothing wanting on my side, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: And however you came by the knowledge of Mr. Friendall's weaknesses, you have improv'd 'em as much as they cou'd bear upon the Conduct of his Wife: if they have not carry'd me as far as you design'd; 'tis the fault of my heaviness, perhaps, that can't be transported into the Woman you'd have me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: There's a fault somewhere.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore, some Women won't speak so plain; but I will own to you, I can't think the worse of you for thinking well of me: Nay, I don't blame you for designing upon me, custome has fashion'd it into the way of living among the men; and you may be i'th' right to all the Town: But let me be i'th' right too to my Sex and to my self: thus far may be excus'd: You've prov'd your Passion and my Vertue try'd; but all beyond that tryal is my crime, and not to be forgiven: therefore I intreat you, don't make it impossible to me for the future, to receive you as a friend; for I must own, I wou'd secure you always for my Friend: Nay more, I will confess my heart to you: If I cou'd make you mine——

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: For ever Yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: But I am marry'd, only pitty me—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pity her! She does not deserve it, that won't better her condition, when she may: But she's marry'd she says; why, that was the best of my reasons of following her at first; and I like her so well, as she's another Man's wife, I shou'd hardly mend the matter by making her my own. I won't think yet my two months thrown away upon her: One time or other, some way or other, I may be the better for her; at least with some other Women: but I begin to believe that every Man loses his labour this way sometimes.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Who can that Woman be?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Wilding's the Man I know.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Then it may be my good Cozen Wittwoud.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Presuming upon the Scarf, which is very like yours, I ventur'd, and spake to her. I shou'd have known Mrs. Wittwoud I believe.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Pray try if you can learn who she is.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: This Place is too publick for a Vindication of this Nature, if you retire into the next room, I may accept of your excuses, upon your Promise of good behaviour, and better Conduct for the future.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'll follow you—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You will be the Man I see, Wilding: The Lady's withdrawn; don't let her stay for you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, Wellvile, 'tis a fortune thrown upon me; and since it came without my seeking, methinks, you should hardly think it worth your courting: She'll bring it about one way of other, you find.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You speak as if I knew the Lady.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I wou'd have you know so much, that she is not worth the honourable care you have of her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Of whom.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: As if you did not know her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Why, 'tis not Mrs. Sightly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have declin'd it as much as I cou'd in regard to a Friend; but when she follows me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Mrs Sightly follow you!
sp.stage: [Mr. Friendall enters and joyns with Mr. Lovemi

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No naming Names, good Wellvile.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay, then I must convince you; I just lest Mrs. Sightly to come to you; She's now in the Company, and I'll carry you to hear me speak to her.———

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Why, this was a terrible disappointment.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: There are Lampoons, Sir, I say no more; But I may do my self reason in one of 'em, and disappoint her yet of her disappointment.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why then Wittwood has put another Woman upon me; and abus'd Mrs. Sightly and me: I am satisfied of the Cheat, and wou'd be assisting to the revenge of it if I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You wou'd not be the instrument, to make it publick your self?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, that I can't consent to.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Then leave it to me: Friendall's a property fit for our several interests: But Lovemore must employ him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am very fit for your purpose, at present, I have met with a little ill usage from a Lady; by not meeting with her: but you may be the better for it, if you please: You shall have the pleasure, and she shall have the reputation of the entrigue.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: I am for all or none.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The rarest accident, Friendall; the reason that you were disappointed in the Park, I can tell you, was, the Lady had appointed to meet Wilding here: She is now withdrawn into the next room in expectation of him; which Wellvile, her old Lover, suspecting, has taxt him of, and ruin'd the design. Now if you wou'd have me, I'll keep up the jealousie between 'em, and give you an opportunity to go in to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: By all means, Lovemore, this was unexpected, and done like a Friend; I owe you a good turn for't, be sure you keep 'em here.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: What are you designing upon Mr. Friendall?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: There's mischief in't; and you may all be the better for't.
sp.stage: Mrs. Teazall pressing in with a Footman upon the Company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: What's the noise there?

sp.speaker: Footman,
sp.p: Madam, here's a rude, unmannerly Gentlewoman presses in upon me, and refuses to pull off her Masque, as your Honour order'd.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: You saucy Rascal you, I shew a better Face than thy Mother had, when she laid thee to the Parish, you Rogue: Prate to me, you Varlet! and an honester one, tho' I say it, than any of the Company: Here's fine work indeed in a civil Family! What, Are you asham'd of your doings, that you won't discover your selves?

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: Mistress, you have the natural privilege of a Masque. And being disguised in your own Face, you may say what you please.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Marry, come up here; Will nothing but a good Face down with you? a Woman has a fine time on't, with your finical fancy: but I want leasure to laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I guess at you: learn to speak without a question, You Fool, before you set up for a Witt.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I know You.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Why then you may be satisfied, I shall think you an Ass.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: Nay, good Mother, you had e'en as good pull off your Masque. You see you are discover'd.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Discover'd you snotty-nos'd Jacanapes! Wou'd I cou'd discover your Master; I wou'd send him a Note of your Name: You are not yet clean from School, and are setting up for the Women forsooth: You have been so us'd to be turn'd up for a Blockhead, as you are, for peeping into every bodys back-door, to find as great a fool as your self: Sirrah, Sirrah, a good Burch Rod for your Mistress; that wou'd tickle your tail, as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Spring,
sp.l: Nay, good your Reverence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: What's the Matter pray?

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Why the wicked ways of Living in this Town, are matter enough for the vexation of any Woman, that has a Girl to look after: God's my life! Can't you keep up your Masquerades, in the primitive institution of making Cuckolds, as it us'd to be, without bringing the young Wenches into the Mystery of Matrimony before their time? Where's my Niece among you? 'tis a burning shame to draw away a poor young Girl into these deboist gallopping doings, as you do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Teazall, not so censorious: Pray where's the harm of a little innocent diversion?

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Innocent diversion, with a Pox to't! for that will be the end on't, at last: very innocent diversion indeed; why, your Musick-meetings, Dancing-meetings, Masquing-meetings, are all but pretences to bring you together: and when you meet, we know what you meet for well enough; 'tis to the same purpose, in good troth: all ends in the innocent diversion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Nay, saith, the Gentlewoman has reason for what she says.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Well, make me thankfull for it; there's one civil Gentleman among you: and really there's a great deal of comfort in opening a poor Woman's case, to a discreet good-natur'd Gentleman: Pray, Sir, hear me; and if you don't allow that I have some cause for what I do, I will be contented never to see Coat-card, nor have Pam in my Pocket agen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: But who are you looking for all this while?

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p:
An untowardly Girl, to be sure, my Cozen Fanny, Madam: she has undone her self, and my hopes of a Husband for her: Gad forgive me, I have no Patience, when I think upon't: last night, Wittwoud forsooth, she carries her to the Musick-meeting; then one Wilding, an impudent Whore-mastering fellow, he carries her home with him, which I cou'd forgive well enough too, if it ended there: but now, when all things were agreed upon, and Mr. Buttybun was to give us a Supper, and sign the Writings, in order to Marry her to
morrow; when the Baggage was call'd upon, to perform her part, whip, she had given us the slip, tuckt up her tail, and run a rogueing after that fellow agen: but I shall light upon her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Wilding, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: O, Sir, are you there? if there be any Justice in England for the Women, I'll have you bound to the Good behaviour; I'll swear the Peace against you my self; for there's no-body safe, young or old, at this rate, if such Whore-masters as you are allow'd to do as you do.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am bound already to behave my self like a Gentleman: I do what good I can, in my Generation; but injure no-body.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, you shall find you have injur'd my Niece, and me, before I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You won't bring it to Westminster, I hope, to be decided, who has most injur'd her; I, by being civil to her, or you, by telling it to all the Town

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Why that's true agen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And let the Company judge, who appears to be most her Enemy; I, in teaching her a very good Trade; or you, in endeavouring to break her, before she's well set up in't.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Nay, now it goes against you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have put her in a very good way; if she manage it well, she'll make more on't, than her Mother made of her Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Nay, 'twas the ruin of her, that I grant you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And let the worst come to the worst, if she fails in this calling: she may begin in another, (as they do in the City sometimes) 'tis but setting up for a Husband at last.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: But that you won't consent to, it seems.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I ha'nt seen your Niece since morning; and then Mrs. Wittwoud oblig'd me to give over my pretensions to her, upon the promise of procuring Mrs. Sightly for me.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.l: Without my knowledge, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Indeed, Madam, you were not to know of the bargain.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Then you don't know where Fanny is?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not I faith, Madam.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: We were just complaining of Mrs. Wittwoud's unkindness to you, as you came in.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: She has been very busie all this night in carrying on an intreigue, between your Niece and some-body: They are retir'd into the next Room; they went out at that door, if you have a mind to be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: I'm sorry, Sir, I 〈◊〉 time to thank you for this favour: I must make haste, for I'm resolv'd to be satisfied.
sp.stage: [Scene draws, shows Friendall and Wittwoud upon a Couch.
sp.l: Very fine! here is a sight indeed!

sp.speaker: Wittw.
sp.l: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: What a pox! disturb a Gentleman's pleasures! and in his own House too! ha! Wittwoud here! Nay then, wou'd you had come sooner: Madam, I beg your pardon for some Liberties I have taken with your Ladyship: But, saith, I took you for Mrs. Sightly.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I never was mistaken in you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You see I had too great a respect for you, and therefore provided you a more deserving—

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: Fool.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And one that had as good-natur'd a design upon Mrs. Sightly, as you had your self.

sp.speaker: Teaz.
sp.p: Nay, now, Gentlewoman, I think 'tis come home to you, and I am glad on't, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: You have paid dear enough for that Scarf; you may keep it for a pattern for your friends, as 'twas borrow'd for: I won't insult over you, and am only pleas'd, that I have scap'd your snares.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: That disappointment is my greatest Curse; and disappointments light upon you all.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: This is your Mistress, Captain.

sp.speaker: Spring.
sp.p: And I gad she shall be mine now in spight of her teeth: For since I find she can be civil upon occasion, I shall beat her into good manners, if she refuses me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Every thing has fallen so much to your advantage, that sure the sault I made may be forgiven: What amends I have in my power, I am ready to make you: my liberty, of what I have to give, is what I value most; and that is yours, when you consent to let me make you mine.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: This is too sudden to be serious: when you're in earnest, you won't need an answer.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They are striking up a Peace on all hands, Gentlemen; we shall be left out of the Treaty.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: There's yet a Lady to declare her self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: Mr. Friendall, I'm sorry you thought it necessary to your pleasures, to make me a witness of my ill usage: you know I can, and have past many things, some Women wou'd think wrongs, as such resent 'em, and return 'em too: but you can tell how I've behav'd my self.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.l: Like a Gentlewoman always, Madam, and my Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.p: The unjust World, let what will be cause of our complaint (as there is cause sufficient still at home:) condemn us to slavery for life: And if by separation we get free, then all our Husband's faults are laid on us: This hard Condition of a Woman's fate, I've often weigh'd, therefore resolv'd to bear: And I have born; O! what have I not born? But patience tires with such oppressing wrongs, when they come home, to triumph over me; and tell the Town, how much I am despis'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: I see we are both disappointed in this affair of Matrimony; it is not the condition you expected; nor has it the advantages I propos'd. Now, Madam, since 'tis impossible to make it happy between us, let us ev'n resolve to make it as easie as we can.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: That must be my business now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: And mine too, I assure you: look you, Madam, your own Relations shall provide for you at pleasure, out of my Estate; I only article that I may have a freedom of visiting you, in the round of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fr.
sp.l: I must be still your Wife, and still unhappy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What alteration this may make in my Fortune with her, I don't know; but I'm glad I have parted 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fr.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I can't be very much displeas'd at the recovery of my liberty, I am only sorry Wittwoud was the occasion of it: For an old blown-upon she-wit, is hardly an intreigue to justifie the separation on my side, or make a man very vain of his Fortune.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: This you must all expect, who marry Fools;
Unless you form 'em early in your Schools,
And make 'em, what they were design'd for, Tools.
